text: if you are a female and b fed up with workplace politics you are not alone in fact youre a growing breed according to a new study which says that women increasingly believe their male colleagues play often immoral power games while they on the other hand are adamant that theyd never resort to such tactics to win promotion women see progress in the modern office as being based on political skill rather than competence they realise that to get on you have to stitch people up stab colleagues in the back and try to appear better than other people all things that they believe men enjoy but which they dont says the studys author kate mackenzie davey of birkbeck college university of london who interviewed women across the country come on girls if politicking really is the only way forward why dont you throw caution to the wind and embrace that good oldfashioned if you cant beat em join em attitude not a chance lament the majority of the women surveyed many of whom justify their decision on the basis of these games being corrupt and unkind people like my boss seem to get their satisfaction out of getting one up on someone else out of winning the power games and i see that as a very masculine attitude to work which i completely reject says one but she adds it probably means ill never get very far nicola stuart a pa from stratford in east london agrees if you want to make it in this office you have to be quick to point the finger when something goes wrong be in with the right cliques and grab as much turf as you can from day one ive refused to lower myself to it other recent studies also show women denying any interest in underhand careerenhancing tactics a recent survey by recruitment agency planet recruit found that twice as many men as women say they are happy to take credit for someone elses work meanwhile of the men questioned said they would be prepared to have sex with their boss if it would get them a higher status job while less than a third of the women said they would do so but says dr mackenzie davey a deep dislike for mercenary strategies isnt the only reason women claim not to get involved in office politics many feel they would fail miserably at attempting to use politics to their advantage this kind of attitude is linked to a lack of confidence and skill in negotiation that women demonstrate right across the work place she says we know that women for example will not apply for a job unless they are confident that they could do all the components of it successfully men on the other hand will apply when they are confident that they could do a fraction of the work if youre going to succeed at playing against the rule book in an office to get somewhere then clearly the latter approach is required debra allcock author of high flying published by the industrial society agrees women are more likely to measure themselves on what they cannot do rather than what they can do underhand tactics which involve playing up their achievements is therefore alien they honestly think they are less deserving not necessarily than men but than any other employee it doesnt help that many more women than men work parttime she adds a whoyouknow type attitude to getting promotion is far more difficult to achieve if youre not there all the time to see who the people are to know and then theres the fact that many women dont like admitting their ambition says mackenzie davey in terms of their social identity it was difficult for many of the women i interviewed to reconcile maintaining a positive image of their femininity with a desire for power prestige and progression aha stop right there if women wont admit to ambition isnt it possible that they wont admit to using the tools to get there either in other words isnt it possible that those who say they wouldnt resort to politicking to get on are telling porkies or at least exaggerating occupational psychologist hannah ellis certainly thinks so office politics like ambition are perceived as masculine and macho and some women therefore have difficulty in positioning themselves within its framework its not necessarily that theyre lying when they say they dont use underhand tactics just that they dont regard their behaviour as such in fact some research has found that women can be far greater political animals than men a recent study from deskdemon a website for pas and secretaries is one in a long line to have discovered that employees on the whole prefer working for men for this very reason cary cooper organisational psychologist at the university of manchester institute of science and technology explains particularly in industries such as law and finance where there are fewer women they remain controlled by the predominant masculine culture the queen bee personality where aggression and macho tactics rule can be very strong its as if women feel the need to be even more political than men to make up for the fact that theyre female underneath the interesting thing is that theyll rarely admit to it on the other hand says ellis you could argue that we are likely to be harder on women than men even when they display the same behaviour we have ingrained notions of what is proper female behaviour that is not political and when they deviate from that we are quick to throw wild accusations she says when a woman tells someone off for instance she may be seen as being aggressive and irrational whereas her male counterpart is seen as assertive and fair sheer hite gender guru and author of sex and business agrees women tend to treat each other as bitch or best friend she says my boss is a bat from hell a bitch on wheels complains one secretary in her latest study according to organisational psychologist marilyn davidson it may be time the debate on office politics moved away from gender altogether the truth is that negative politiking is most likely to occur in offices where job security is high irrespective of the balance of males and females says professor davidson it makes even the least naturally competitive people start vying with colleagues in a fight to keep their job excessive competition at the top of industries such as banking and retail can mean companies in these sectors are the worst offenders says beverley stone author of confronting office politics people redefine company goals to suit their own purposes managers are wellplaced to empirebuild and conflicts tend to arise between departments the trend for hotdesking also breeds office politics says christopher early organisational psychologist at indiana university without any space to call their own people feel unstable undervalued and are rife for misusing power mackenzie davey adds that the decreasingly hierarchical organisational structures that are currently in vogue may also be to blame in the oldfashioned bureaucratic structures its clear and explicit who holds power and who doesnt she says in the flatter organisations its much more difficult to know who are the people who can pull strings but before you feel tempted to run screaming from your office in an attempt to get away from all thats political take comfort in the views of jane clarke author of office politics backstabbing bitching buckpassing bullying mention office politics and thats what people think of but in fact politics is simply defined as the informal rather than the formal way of getting things done and thats inevitable in any environment whether its a country company or even home where there are conflicting objectives clashing priorities and different styles says dr clarke in fact she adds office politics are constructive when employees learn where the power lies understand how to obtain it for themselves and have the skill to use it to pursue their goals its only destructive when motivation is purely selfish or unethical

text: the equal opportunities commission yesterday slammed britains progress in closing the pay gap between men and women after official figures showed it had widened among top earners according to the annual new earnings survey published yesterday the differential between mens and womens hourly pay narrowed by just between and last year leaving them still behind their male counterparts men earn an average of per hour women earn among highest earners the pay gap is wider still with the top of men paid more than a week up from against for the top of women a rise of the new figures reveal the shameful truth that britain is still failing to make any significant progress towards closing the gender pay gap said julie mellor chairman of the eoc women will remain the poorer sex until there is a radical change of working culture in all sectors and at all levels an eoc report on women in management also published yesterday showed that although of managers are now female they are still paid less per hour than male managers the proportion of female managers has only reached in sectors traditionally associated with women such as education health and social services barbara roche the minister for women admitted there was still much work to do in closing the pay gap but denied it was solely the responsibility of government we are committed to tackling the circumstances that lead to the pay gap and to doing this in partnership with business she said but this is not solely a matter for government what is also needed is a cultural change among employers so they properly value womens contribution to business success the government has introduced measures for reducing the gap including pay questionnaires making it easier for women to find out how much their male colleagues earn earnings differences vary by region the survey reveals with women in london taking home of their male counterparts hourly wage but women in wales earning as much as men

text: the fast growing demand for daily nannies to look after children whose parents both work has boosted incomes in central london by nearly four times the rate of inflation according a survey by nursery world magazine salaries for nannies in other parts of the country have also risen sharply imposing increasingly heavy financial burdens on couples who return to their jobs a daily nanny in london now earns an average of per year a rise of over the previous year in order to pay that wage a mother who goes back to work must earn at least a year before tax after paying her nannys tax wages and national insurance the mothers contribution to the rest of the familys expenditure is in effect zero liz roberts the editor of nursery world said tax relief for parents on nannies salaries would enable more families to take advantage of flexible high quality childcare at the moment many mothers are returning to work for absolutely no financial gain it is estimated that there are at least represented a rise over the previous year middle and low income families can claim tax credits to wards the cost of leaving their children with childminders or at nurseries both of which are now text: the government is set to miss its target of creating m new childcare places by because of bureaucracy and a failure to encourage entrepreneurs a report will claim tomorrow thinktank demos and consultants genderquake say that ministers need to help create a new industry to meet the needs of working families if the goals of their national childcare strategy are to be delivered the report highlights the ever more complex and precarious childcare arrangements being cobbled together by working families blaming this situation on the fact that the number of registered childminders fell by a third during the s while the government says it will need newlyqualified childcare workers to meet its targets the report points to recent estimates that show a total of up workers including unqualified staff are needed report author helen wilkinson said we must stop treating childcare as a burden that society has to bear grudgingly just so women can be allowed to go back to work there is an opportunity to grow a new and dynamic industry which can meet the needs of todays working families and at the same time provide employment and socially responsible business opportunities her report lays down a series of recommendations to improve the situation including the creation of a national childcare agency to help develop publicprivate provision it also proposes employers that invest in childcare should get tax breaks a new fund should be set up to attract investment and a recruitment campaign should be launched to bring men into the industry currently men make up less than of nursery nurses and just of playworkers the scale of the shortages in care provision are masked the report states by a big increase in the number of family members who act as unpaid childminders it adds that this will never be a solution to childcare problems and highlights the fact that four out of grandparents want less involvement in family duties

text: the first ever uk national childcare strategy unveiled in was a historic event but four years on the child care gap remains significant and the government is in danger of failing to deliver on its own target of m new childcare places by why is this at the most basic level the demand for child care services is far outstripping supply at a time when the recruitment challenges facing the sector are greater than teacher and nursing shortages the number of qualified childcare workers would need to increase by over the next four years according to government figures the childcare commission which reported in estimated that over childcare workers would be needed over the next four years the cost of care also remains prohibitive for many working parents parents typically bear of the costs the typical cost for a family with two children one preschool the other school age is per year so many parents are left struggling to stitch together precarious childcare arrangements often reliant on grandparents or other friends and family employers for their part have been curiously absent from the child care debate partly because government policy has done little to encourage and reward familyfriendly employers in autumn the performance and innovation unit the governments own thinktank decided belatedly to conduct a review of the national childcare strategy no doubt the review will aid the decision making process in the run up to the spring budget but money alone is not enough beyond the headlines and statistics about the childcare gap individuals and organisations are working in imaginative ways to deliver change on the ground but the system is disabling rather than enabling departmental responsibility for childcare is unclear and holistic government is lacking peoples energies are spent navigating the funding maze rather than on developing and delivering childcare services unwieldy bureaucratic child care partnerships the primary vehicle for delivering change locally have lacked focus been shortterm in their approach and have suffered skills deficits in marketing and business development partly as a consequence child care entrepreneurs small scale as well as large have not received the support they need to grow their services and enterprises a number of announcements during illustrated the governments desire to accelerate delivery on the ground and on the surface at least there appears to be an increased emphasis on the business of child care new funding commitments are bringing much needed capital to child care entrepreneurs and poor areas the government has also established an expert group to ensure access to public and private finance and a m business support programme for child care and nursery education providers has been unveiled with business advisers available to support childcare partnerships these are important new initiatives and they reflect a clear shift in priorities towards business development and shared investment in innovative childcare solutions however they do not fit clearly within a strategic framework for defining and delivering the next phase of the national childcare strategy nor do they grapple decisively enough with the problems impeding delivery on the ground after all if we take the business of child care seriously rather than seeing childcare as a burden which taxpayers bear this requires much more than incremental reform it means recognising that child care is as important to the national economy as an effective transport system it means recognising that the national childcare strategy provides an opportunity to grow a new and dynamic industry which can meet the needs of working parents but which can also provide employment and socially responsible business opportunities and it means creating the intermediary institutions which can enable and grow the fledgling childcare industry one solution would be for a childcare development agency to take responsibility for the child care industry this nondepartmental public agency could be founded through a publicprivate partnership with start up finance from central government its job would be to incubate and accelerate the growth of the industry government funds could be matched by privatesector funds including the venture capital industry but it could have nonprofit status to allow it to access the broadest range of funding sources financial surplus should be reinvested into growing more childcare businesses strategic investment business incubation and support engaging employers in the childcare challenge empowering parents and communities to help themselves and sharing knowledge and experience will be critical if the first ever national childcare strategy is to go down in the history books as a turning point for working families and the catalyst for growing a new and dynamic sector of the economy helen wilkinson is the author of creche barriers how britain can grow its childcare industry published by genderquake and demos

text: the forgotten heroine of the race to unravel the mystery of human dna is to be honoured posthumously as part of a government crusade against sexism in science rosalind franklin has become a feminist cause clbre the dedicated scientist held back by her male colleagues refusal to acknowledge her vital role in one of the most important scientific discoveries of the century while the three male scientists who helped establish the doublehelix structure of dna shared the nobel prize for their breakthrough based in large part on franklins detailed xray images of atoms she won little public recognition and her early death robbed her of later fame rosy was dismissed in james watsons account of the discovery the double helix as a buttonedup bluestocking who her scientific partner believed had to go or be put in her place only recently has her reputation begun to be restored now patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary is to create a franklin medal in her honour to raise the profile of other women scientists with a annual prize for exceptional innovation hewitt has also ordered an inquiry headed by professor susan greenfield the neurologist and presenter of the bbc tv series brain story into the barriers keeping women out of top science jobs a report to be published by the government tomorrow maximising returns reveals that at any one time there are around women science and engineering graduates not working mostly after leaving to have children only a third of those who return from a career break take jobs that use their university qualifications we have a lot of very clever women going to waste said a source close to hewitt who will outline the findings in a speech this week to the daphne jackson trust which helps women scientists return to their careers patricia is very clear that the economy is losing out if you are only concentrating on half your potential workforce franklin who died of ovarian cancer at the age of faced the barriers hewitt is now trying to overcome she nearly lost her place at cambridge university after her father who disapproved of degrees for women refused to pay her tuition fees he was eventually shamed into it by her aunt and mother franklins break came when she was hired by kings college in to work on the dna project as a crystallographer mapping the location of atoms within a structure at the time women were not even allowed to take lunch in the senior common room her partnership with maurice wilkins who was racing francis crick and james watson to find the structure of dna was strained apparently wilkins resented her involvement but when he showed her dna images to watson their rival realised she was on the right track when franklin announced in that she was leaving for another job wilkins wrote to the cambridge pair that our dark lady leaves us next week at last the decks are clear but by the time his letter reached crick and watson they had announced their discovery of the doublehelix based in no small part on franklins research crick later admitted franklin was only two steps away from the solution when she left kings it was not sexism that denied franklin the nobel prize in she died before it was awarded and it is not given posthumously but the prize can only be shared three ways raising questions over whether she would have been given the credit had she lived franklins sister jennifer glyn is delighted about the medal scheme rosalind would have been amazed and immensely pleased at this recognition of her work she said although the number of women with science engineering and technology degrees rose by a fifth between and they are sparsely represented at the highest levels there have only ever been female nobel science laureates the women that science forgot astronomer caroline herschel was the first woman to discover a comet by the time she died in she had mapped thousands of galaxies overshadowed by her brother the astronomer royal she played down her achievements lise meitner described by einstein as germanys marie curie proposed the theory of nuclear fission meitner who was jewish fled germany in and the nobel prize for chemistry went to her collaborator otto hahn physicist jocelyn bell burnell was a research student at cambridge when she tripped over the discovery of pulsars tiny superdense stars with strong magnetic fields it led to a nobel prize in for her supervisor dorothy hodgkin barred from chemistry club meetings when she arrived at oxford because of her sex went on to become the only british woman to win the nobel prize for discoveries on the chemical structures of penicillin and insulin

text: fathers groups yesterday welcomed the decision of one of britains top chief executives to quit his ayear job to spend more time with his wife and four children fathers direct said danny oneils decision to step down as chief executive of the britannic group so he could be with his triplets as they grew up would be an inspiration to fathers across britain after finding he could not successfully balance family life with the pressures of running one of britains largest companies mr oneil has quit his post and plans to work three days a week as a consultant mr oneil said he began rethinking his priorities this year when his eldest daughter siobhan left home for university climbing the career ladder meant long hours and a great deal of travel and he felt he had missed out on her childhood the consultancy which will pay about half what he previously earned will allow him to spend much more time with his nineyearold triplets patrick conor and caitlin at their home in glasgow this means that fathers lower down the corporate structure will also feel able to say their children are a priority corporations will have to realise that men need the same sort of flexibility at work as women enjoy said jack osullivan of fathers direct men in britain work some of the longest hours in europe a report by the european commission network on childcare revealed fathers with children aged under work an average of hours per week mr oneil said commuting between glasgow london and birmingham where britannic has its headquarters took up an immense amount of time when this was added to frequent foreign trips his worklife balance seemed out of kilter i have been at the top for a while now and have proved i can do this job he said but i have not had the right balance between my personal life and work the triplets are at an age where i want to spend more time with them and they want to do more things with me mr oneils decision has the backing of his wife patricia who is also giving up her part time job as a practice nurse so that she too can concentrate on their children there is strong evidence to suggest most men increase their working hours after their children are born largely because their partners tend to reduce their hours and the shortfall in income has to be met

text: it has been heralded as the cornerstone of new labours drive to modernise public services and tackle social exclusion but policy experts have warned there is still scant evidence of joint working a report on health and social services partnerships by leading thinktank the kings fund due to be published later this month has found little to indicate the initiative is delivering better quality care the report partnerships under pressure will also warn that the governments plans to impose structural solutions to joint working such as care trusts and its focus on acute care are hindering the development of alternative sustainable local partnerships penny banks fellow in health and social care at the thinktank said the evidence is yet to come that they are delivering its conclusion mirrors that of an assessment of five jointworking programmes by parliaments spending watchdog which found that only three of the government schemes the rough sleepers unit rsu early years development and childcare partnerships and business link partnerships have achieved tangible benefits so far the number of rough sleepers has fallen by from in june to in june the target to provide a free parttime nursery place for all four year olds had been met by march and new childcare places had been created exceeding the target of by the productivity and profitability of businesses assisted by business link partnerships is also higher than those of nonassisted businesses but the national audit office nao said it was too early for there to be any measurable longterm benefit for the remaining two projects sure start which supports disadvantaged preschool children and exports promotion body british trade international the report joining up to improve public services also found that there is still little joint working between central government departments while local organisations often lack commitment to the approach for example the rsu found it difficult to persuade councils and nhs trusts to treat rough sleepers as a priority unless it provided them with direct funding the auditors added that joint working does not always lead to greater cost efficiency for example the average cost of providing a childcare placement is with early years development and childcare partnerships compared with under previous arrangements however the cost of reducing rough sleeping has dropped considerably prior to the establishment of the rsu it cost on average to take one person off the streets this has now fallen to this decrease suggests that the provision of more integrated services including health and social support is more cost effective in helping rough sleepers and preventing rough sleeping than previous arrangements states the report but mps from the public accounts select committee have criticised the reports value given the lack of financial data available to draw meaningful conclusions about the impact of joint working the report warns if parliament is not able to identity total expenditure and outcomes achieved by joint initiatives then parliament cannot take assurances that taxpayers money has been well spent labour mp alan williams pointed out that they could not check this because only the costs of central government expenditure were available for the nao to evaluate the cost effectiveness of the programmes how can we know if workers from mainstream services exacerbating staff shortages another obstacle to the wider takeup of health and social care partnerships identified by the kings fund is the fast pace of nhs modernisation a problem recognised by the chief inspector of social services denise platt in her th annual report last august despite these difficulties ms mcdonald and naiomi eisenstadt head of sure start told the select committee that joint working was being extended to cover health inequalities children at risk drug programmes and the voluntary sector through a series of crosscutting spending text: in todays workplace young men are often spoken of as a lost tribe who must be protected in case the women grab all the glory against this comes an academic paper that shows that young women are lost and confused too dr kate mackenzie davey of londons birkbeck college told this years british psychological association conference on organisational psychology that female graduates feel compromised by the office politics required to advance their careers her research found that the female graduates divided work into crawling and backstabbing on the one hand and quiet efficiency on the other with the former likely to be rewarded at the expense of the latter nearly all those interviewed assumed that they fell into the quiet efficient category and were resigned to failing in their careers they assumed that the exhibitionism they believed necessary for success comes naturally to men and they tended to describe what men do as games and nice women dont want to play those games anyway although some admit they would not be so nice if they thought they had a chance of winning it is ironic that those interviewed feel socially excluded because it is assumed that women are racing ahead on the strength of their superior social skills davey found that women regarded assessments as an opportunity to take on board constructive criticism rather than as an opportunity to show off and that they spoke in meetings only when they had something relevant to say the belief that quiet efficiency will be overlooked may be selffulfilling because by valuing themselves for their efficiency they are more reluctant to to talk themselves into jobs for which they do not believe they are fully qualified the root of the problem seems to be that young women still consider that success can be achieved only at the expense of personal integritythe positive note that comes out of the research is that some young women see the disadvantages they believe they face as a challenge and are more determined to become successful on their terms rather than sell out

text: can the government really achieve its year target of eliminating child poverty research published today by the daycare trust the national childcare campaign group questions whether the range of initiatives aimed at disadvantaged children in england is either sufficiently coherent or sustainable in the longer term to ensure that the target is met it is thought there are at least different funding streams associated with antipoverty schemes emanating from the department of health the home office the department of transport local government and the regions and the treasury and despite the impressive number of initiatives their coverage is by no means comprehensive by contrast the welsh assembly has decided to adopt a unified approach creating a single support grant fund that will bring together all the main schemes and funding flows aimed at supporting children and young people in wales jane hutt welsh minister for health and social services describes the new children and youth support fund or cymorth as coherent and efficient the daycare trust research carried out by hilary land professor of family policy and child welfare at bristol university analyses the range of health education and childcare initiatives aimed at children living in poverty in england it concludes that agencies both voluntary and statutory are frequently hindered by the sheer number and variety of initiatives and that the mix of programmes is unlikely to meet the needs of anything like all children suffering the effects of poverty and social exclusion large numbers of disadvantaged children land points out live in areas not targeted for help and the shortterm financing of many schemes means that the agencies involved are unable to intervene and provide support in the longer term they cannot build and maintain the human capacity necessary to turn round longestablished problems associated with exclusion and deprivation it does not follow that land the trust or indeed other childcare agencies take a negative stance against programmes such as sure start or the national childcare strategy nor against the childcare tax credit or working families tax credit neera sharma policy adviser at childrens charity barnardos says sure start which by should be helping disadvantaged young children is demonstrating that sustained action brings tangible benefits the process of mainstreaming good practice emerging from the programme should provide a lesson for the government about the importance of moving away from shorttermism and narrow targeting sharma adds yet even by sure start will be reaching only about one in three of all unders living in poverty similarly as land outlines in her report meeting the child poverty challenge the national childcare strategy has delivered only a very modest improvement in services from meeting the needs of one in nine unders in to one in seven in and not only are there very marked regional variations in provision of day nurseries playgroups childminders and outofschool clubs but over the past year there has been a net reduction in the number of available childminders and playgroup places not surprisingly the daycare trust is particularly concerned about this as a result of demand for childcare outstripping supply it says the typical cost of a fulltime nursery place is now a week rising to in inner london while a fulltime place with a childminder is some a week a recent survey of community nurseries with fees below the market rate found two in three reporting that they were threatened with closure stephen burke the trusts director points out that parents still pay threequarters of the cost of childcare although working families on lower incomes now get tax credit help this commonly amounts to less than a third of the cost of a nursery place at the same time the vast majority of workless families get no help at all which affects m children of whom only can access services paid for by their local authority says burke millions of children in workless families are therefore missing out on learning and development opportunities preschool education however continues to be developed as a universal service funded by general taxation all fouryearolds are now guaranteed a place and by the end of this year the guarantee is to be extended to cover twothirds of threeyearolds critics say this exemplifies a lack of joinedup thinking by government possibly a result of wellintentioned pressure on whitehall departments to come up with ideas and schemes as a result as lands research suggests labours original commitment to push through an integrated programme of educational financial and social care help for the m children getting a poor start in life has led to something of a muddle this is particularly evident in support available for disabled children and their families almost children and young people have some form of disability and are almost twice as likely as their peers to live in low income households yet as sharma points out less than of government funding for local early years and childcare partnerships a cornerstone of the national childcare strategy are aimed directly at meeting the needs of disabled children so there continues to be a lack of good quality affordable childcare for them campaigners in england are now casting envious eyes across offas dyke the new welsh children and youth support fund will bring together the funding flows and structures associated with among others sure start the national childcare strategy the childrens fund and waless youth access initiative and play grant there will be a specific grant for the first five years starting in april next year but thereafter the funding will be in mainstream grant allocations every welsh council is required to have childrens partnerships with relevant agencies and every local partnership is expected to submit detailed plans and applications for funding by this october many funded projects will be delivered in wales through integrated local childrens centres though sure starts special focus on the underfours will be retained i want to maximise the benefits of these links says hutt for example there are common themes of play and support for parenting skills that are relevant to all stages of childhood while priority will be given to the most disadvantaged localities she adds that the more holistic the support the better the outcome the plan gets wholehearted support from joe howsam who speaks on childcare issues in wales for the association of directors of social services wed been concerned about the plethora of planning documents and strategies he says were very pleased that the welsh assembly has taken this issue seriously meeting the child poverty challenge text: parents of toddlers can save nearly every school term under the expanding free nursery places scheme although whether you are entitled to free provision depends primarily on where you live the government has pledged that by september it will fund free nursery places for all threeyearolds whose parents want them starting the term after their third birthday the scheme guarantees five twoandahalf hour sessions per week this is already the case for fouryearolds who are entitled to a free parttime place in an eligible setting which may be a school nursery or reception class a private nursery or playgroup and as the government gears up for universal provision for threeyearolds in which means a target of giving at least of threeyearolds access to a free place some parents who pay for their toddlers to attend a private provider will find they are already entitled to a free parttime place and a consequent reduction in the fees they are paying the term after their child turns three but many parents are confused about whether their children are entitled to a free place during this interim period at present entitlement to a free place which can reduce private nursery fees by up to per term depends primarily on where you live and a range of criteria such as social deprivation in your area the rollout of central government funding for threeyearolds nursery places to local authorities is being allocated on the basis of need if you live for example in newcastle upon tyne or the inner london borough of islington both of which have long had a high level of commitment to the provision of nursery education and are recognised as deprived areas by central government your threeyearold will automatically have access to a free parttime nursery place if you want it regardless of your level of wealth newcastle city council says that of the areas threeyearolds currently have access to a free good quality early years education place islington too can offer free parttime places to all threeyearolds whose parents want them in fact of islingtons children have fulltime places in councilrun nurseries attached to primary schools before the age of four islington is pushed however to quite reach the governments target of universal takeup because it does not suit parents in certain sectors of the authoritys mobile and multicultural population to send their children to an early years setting some prefer for example to keep their preschool children at home within the extended family but areas like newcastle and islington which already receive enough funding to provide free nursery places for all their threeyearolds are not the norm far more local authorities as yet receive only sufficient funding to provide free places to a percentage of those who want them and it is down to each authoritys early years partnership to decide the criteria for how that money should be allocated richmonduponthames in surrey for example which is largely an affluent area but with pockets of relative deprivation has approximately threeyearolds some of them already attend councilmaintained nursery classes around attend nonmaintained private settings and the remaining either stay at home or have other care arrangements the funding richmond received for the spring term was sufficient to pay for free parttime places not a figure that would easily divide between the children in eligible settings so its early years partnership strategy team had to work out a fair set of criteria the first was social need with children identified by its social services department receiving free places second it decided that all threeyearolds in settings in the boroughs four most disadvantaged wards would get free places third all children living in these four wards who attended settings outside their boundaries received a free place these three criteria accounted for of the available places the rest were then allocated by date of birth with places going to the oldest threeyearolds those born before june working all of this out was described by one team member as an administrative and mathematical nightmare and not one easily explained to parents but allocating free places for next term should be much easier as the government moves towards universal funding richmond will get enough money to pay for free places split between the children in eligible settings this should allow an acrosstheboard policy of giving a free parttime place to every threeyearold for the two terms prior to their fourth birthday parents who want to check on their own childs entitlement to a free nursery place should start by contacting their local authoritys childrens information service and asking what the local po sition is you should then make sure that the nursery provider you want your child to attend is participating in your local authoritys plan for nursery education the final twist is that if you choose a provider which has decided not to participate your child will never be entitled to a free place something worth remembering when picking a nursery for a baby or toddler where you expect them to stay until they start school childrens information service tel or wwwchildcarelinkgovuk

text: how equal is stcentury woman in the workplace when it comes to management of managers are women yet they earn considerably less than their male counterparts less per hour according to new figures from the equal opportunities commission there has been significant progress since the mids the number of female executives has doubled and the number of female company directors has tripled despite these increases only one in company directors are women the eocs report into british management reveals that female managers are more concentrated in certain careers and clusters continue in particular industries there are plenty of them in personnel training and industrial relations yet there are fewer than one in five it managers in some industries they remain non existent at certain levels for example there are no female chief constables a higher proportion of women managers work in the public sector than in the private sector and they constitute twothirds of managers in health and social work and just in construction the findings are not a huge surprise says eoc chairwoman julie mellor they confirm our suspicions that women simply arent represented at senior level in many industries what is particularly disappointing is how big the impact of raising children is on womens careers female managers are much less likely to have dependent children than their male colleagues the eoc remains concerned about britains glass ceiling where senior positions are still mysteriously elusive to women in some industries the report says the eoc would like to see employers opening nontraditional opportunities through staff development and improved recruitment practices sarah best senior policy advisor at the confederation of british industry suggests a few ideas that these companies might implement we could learn a thing or two from the us and adopt best practice such as mentoring networking and career tracking schemes maledominated industries could also do with an image makeover she says employers have actively to change the image of their companies and this has to work its way down to universities colleges and schools careers advisors in schools have to be more imaginative and ensure females arent just channelled into the traditional stereotypical industries such as social services she also believes the state should provide childcare behavioural expert and corporate trainer judi james says the reason women are highly represented in certain industries is not due to any genderspecific psychology its a really iffy stereotype to think women prefer the caring professions the problem is that the doors of opportunity are far more visible and open in those industries and this is not necessarily the case in the private sector or in maledominated industries james has been working with large numbers of female graduates who are choosing to work in the financial sector at the moment more women than men are moving into accountancy but i dont know what happens to them after that when i see people being groomed for partnership level i dont see many women the government also believes that career attitudes of men and women are creating pay differentials women have traditionally seen certain highly paid sectors of the economy as unattractive speaking at a recent conference on women in it trade and industry secretary patricia hewitt said the current situation is bad for women it means they are missing out on opportunities to earn the higher wages available in the it sector its also bad for business and bad for the economy the governments strategy is to encourage more women to take up careers in science engineering and technology set free it software is being supplied by us software company macromedia to schools running computer clubs ambassadors of set are to visit schools to encourage girls in particular to choose the subjects as longterm careers and it compass a free online advice service for women is soon to be launched up to m is also being made available for the it sector from the dtis work life balance challenge fund this provides consultancy support for employees wanting to introduce innovative working practices an it industry dominated by men is using only half the available talent and creativity that is a particular cause for concern in an industry that despite current economic conditions has a growing demand for skilled labour said hewitt the eoc report makes recommendations to improve equality in the underrepresented industries it suggests promoting parttime work and flexible working and says employers have a duty to discourage the long hours culture james goes as far as to suggest that women may not be visible in these industries through choice i think women may be more ahead of the game than many think she says some of these senior jobs such as company directors arent up to much a lot of people are missing out on having an enjoyable life id like to know what these jobs have to offer thats so great ok youve got power but often what you can do is dictated by shareholders the working environment is solitary and if you make loads of money you dont have the time to enjoy it if women choose not to take certain senior managerial positions that is an individual matter but if a glass ceiling is suspected what can they do to break through it if there is resistance to progression then women may have to think creatively the climb up the ladder may not be linear says james women have to look at other ways of getting there it may mean moving sideways for a while or leapfrogging through certain jobs executive coach ian mcdermott says that it may be a case of managing upwards it is often senior staff who generate obstacles at work he says start to think of those above you as customers or clients you need to make them perceive you as someone who makes their life easier who can supply otherwise unavailable skills and information maintain a good rapport with them and make it clear that you are supporting them rather than acting as a threat for more information about the eoc log onto wwweocorguk and for the set initiative visit wwwsetwomengovuk

text: childcare costs have risen by up to per cent in the past year and the chancellors tax credits for working mothers may be to blame a new report to be published this week reveals a nursery place for a toddler now costs an average of a year almost as much as a minor private school with rates soaring even higher in london and the south east the report is expected to show that the average nursery place for a child under two now costs a week against less than last year a rise of more than four times the rate of inflation british parents already pay the highest childcare bills in europe the daycare trust a think tank warns in its report that the governments attempts to help working parents through tax credits may be fuelling the rise in childcare costs unscrupulous nursery owners have been able to hike prices safe in the knowledge that government handouts will soak up the cost for many parents the news comes as tony blairs whitehall troubleshooting unit the performance and innovation unit piu is completing a secret report expected to highlight problems in the governments childcare strategy including growing pressure for a review of how the tax credit works stephen burke of the daycare trust said parents reliant on nurseries to enable them to work had no choice but to pay the going rate parents are trapped there is a real shortage of places so demand is outstripping supply and at the same time there are more and more women in the workforce with young children he said there is some anecdotal evidence even that the childcare tax credit has led to an increase in prices because its just given providers yet more ammunition to put up prices the levels of childcare tax credit were upgraded in the last budget and i think this shows there will need to be further increases but there is a fundamental question about whether that is only helping to stoke the market rather than delivering more childcare the piu report overseen by education minister baroness ashton but heavily influenced by the treasury is expected to back technical changes to make the tax credit easier to claim however it is also expected to highlight fears that the credit is skewing the market for nursery care campaigners now want ministers to switch money into building new nurseries creating competition that drives costs down rather than hoping that giving cash to parents will stimulate demand and encourage more daycare providers to set up in business we should not underestimate the fact that we wont get another chance on this said lisa harker deputy director of another thinktank the institute for public policy research ippr which has led a research project on childcare there are only so many times you can reexamine a strategy and its extremely important not just to consider how we improve the existing system but to look at the year picture browns fondness for tax credits to resolve all problems has already created tensions within the government prompting arguments that too much is spent on a complicated system that many parents do not understand childcare tax credit is paid as part of the working families tax credit claimed by million britons and comes as cash through the pay packet administered by employers it covers up to per cent of the cost of daycare or childminders up to a maximum of for one child and for two children or more it can only be used to pay for registered services not nannies or informal carers the working families tax credit will be replaced in this springs budget by an integrated childrens credit combining the childcare elements with universal child benefit

text: the national childcare strategy has been one of the governments flagship policies but it is failing to deliver change at the pace and scale required why is this a report published by the institute of fiscal studies today helps to explain what has been going wrong the ifs report has two important conclusions having children remains a significant barrier to the employment opportunities of mothers and the lack of accessible and affordable childcare is having an adverse impact on mothers returning to the labour market put more bluntly the current strategy is not working and there is a significant economic cost the figures in the ifs report show strikingly that mothers especially those with younger children are substantially less likely to be in paid employment than women without children the problem is especially acute for single mothers of single mothers do not work and it does not resolve itself when children are old enough to go to school there is no sudden increase in the employment of mothers with schoolage children the childcare gap is a significant constraint on the ability of mothers to return to the labour market about one quarter of nonworking mothers report that they would like to work but are prevented from doing so by having to look after children one in mothers working parttime say that they would increase their hours if affordable and accessible childcare was available partly because of these problems the majority of working families depend on some informal care from family friends and neighbours the government has focused on providing subsidies such as the nursery education grant and the working families tax credit to make childcare more affordable but the ifs research raises questions about this strategy while lower childcare prices were associated with greater use of formal childcare the working families tax credit was found to have a relatively high cost to government and a marginal impact in increasing mothers employment it raised the employment rate by just for single parents and had practically no impact on mothers with partners what then are the implications for government strategy perhaps the most significant is that public resources need to tackle the supply side systematically and aggressively targeting investment at childcare providers as well as providing more effective subsidies for parents that could be done by for example introducing a childcare tax allowance so that childcare costs could be a legitimate expense as well as by reforming the working families tax credit this implies a significant boost to public investment despite an increase in public resources since the state contributes less to childcare provision than almost every major economy while british parents pay the highest childcare costs in europe the childcare sector is ripe for expansion a recent study of nursery provision by market analysts laing buisson put the value of the uk childrens day care nurseries market at just over bn in like the childcare sector in general the childrens nurseries market has grown rapidly in the past years and is now more than five times bigger than at the start of the s as the charts show the vast bulk of this growth is coming from the commercial marketplace and large nursery chains are beginning to take market share from the single nursery providers as investors wake up to the value of childcare as a business if the government focuses public investment on supporting and capitalising childcare entrepreneurs in the notfor profit as well as commercial sector they will accelerate the growth of the sector and tackle supply side problems as more places become available so prices should fall and formal childcare should become more affordable for families subsidies available to parents especially lowerincome ones should continue and be extended but would also benefit from being underpinned by a strategy for tackling the supply side and accelerating the growth of the sector as a whole this cannot be achieved overnight and the government will need to create a framework to develop the industry increase the level of public investment and target it more effectively genderquake and demoss recent report creche barriers recommended the creation of a national childcare development agency with a dedicated childcare fund which would encourage publicprivate partnerships and act as an incubator for new childcare enterprises not for profit as well as commercial as the chart shows there is scope to develop market share among notforprofit childcare enterprises and government could play a leading role in this tax breaks for employers encouraging investment in employee and community childcare provision should also be introduced to engage and involve employers this strategic framework would enable the government to lead by example investing public resources in the marketplace and encouraging venture capitalists and private equity investors and employers to see childcare businesses as socially responsible investments in every crisis there is an opportunity and so it is with childcare the government has a historic opportunity to develop a new and dynamic industry which delivers equality for women meets the needs of todays working families and children and provides employment and socially responsible business opportunities helen wilkinson is director of genderquake a consultancy dealing with equality and diversity issues and an associate of demos

text: the child support agency established in and about to be overhauled again has become one of the most derided of government agencies in there were reforms that reduced the amount that many absent fathers would have to pay but these were complex and still produced results many claimed were anomalous so the law has been changed again with effect from next month at first only new applications will be affected but existing orders will gradually be brought into line the basic formula will be simple so long as the absent parent earns between and per week after tax national insurance and pension contributions he will have to pay for one child for two and for three or more the other parents income is no longer taken into account but the amount paid is reduced by up to if the paying text: childcare clubs relied on by working mothers to occupy their youngsters after school hours are under threat of closure according to a new study the survey by kids club network found that twothirds of the clubs which look after thousands of british children from toddlers to teens said their funding was not secure even for the next year almost eight in were worried about their longterm future of those with concerns nearly a quarter said that if things did not improve they might have to close triggering crises for working parents and potentially leaving a flood of older children to entertain themselves on the streets others would raise fees which some parents could not afford or axe places and services the snapshot of clubs represents the early findings of a study of more than centres all in innercity and deprived areas set up under the governments flagship national childcare strategy to help single mothers back to work there are also fears for the future of some private nursery schools used by wealthier parents of preschool children according to the national day nursery association ndna it warned this weekend that government plans for schools to provide childcare facilities after hours could force some of its members out of business what closure means is that parents who are working will have to consider whether they can carry on or will have to make arrangements for their kids which are not what they hoped for said anne longfield of kids club network which represents outofschool clubs outofschool provision was identified by ministers as one of the key gaps meant to be plugged by the government strategy longfield said the crunch would come in the next months as initial lottery funding awarded to set up the clubs runs out leaving fledgling brightest and the best in future they are going to have to be able to prove that they provide equal pay students need as much information as possible when they are making decisions about their future if an employer cannot show they take equal pay seriously students might well ask themselves how much they value their staff we know employers dont set out to cheat women most say discrimination is a hidden problem that is precisely why employers need to review their pay systems to make sure they are not shortchanging women she said billboards advertising the new campaign why are women graduates still going cheap were today floated down the thames on a barge to mark international womens day owain james president of the national union of students said it is unbelievable that in the st century women are not paid equally the evidence shows that despite equal and often better academic success the disparity in pay still exists between male and female graduates nearly half of all students said average salary gets progressively wider among older graduates kat fletcher nus womens officer said we find that pay inequalities are further exacerbated for women who seek to return to work after text: decades of equal pay battles have left women earning only an average of of mens earnings the government and other parts of the establishment regularly wring their hands over this unfairness which is caused partly by discrimination within jobs but much more by the fact that women tend to do work that is lowerpaid anyway in the public sector at least the government could try to redress the balance but the subject is rarely discussed in these terms however you choose to look at it female occupations are less well paid than male ones compare for instance the mostly female jobs of secretary hairdresser teacher and speech therapist with the higherpaid more male dominated professions of accountant it specialist and steelworker occupational segregation accounts for the largest part of equal pay differentials says nick page pay specialist at the chartered institute of personnel and development cipd research published by the department for education and employment last may on pay levels among apprentices showed a gender pay gap even for workers aged apprenticeships in engineering and electronics largely held by males were the best paid at an average of a week and respectively women apprentices training in early years childcare and education received and hairdressers got so in engineering and hairdressing the men earned double pay research body incomes data services ids said these findings reinforce the notion that the gender pay gap cannot be tackled effectively without measures aimed at reducing occupational segregation since a disproportionate number of women are still finding work in lowpaid sectors at an early stage we narrowed the issue to two jobs by asking should a police officer be paid more than a nurse the nurses of them female start at salaries behind those of the police who are male the gap widens as their careers progress a strong argument for paying nurses at least as much as the police is that nursing is almost entirely a graduate profession while policing is not only about to of metropolitan police recruits have degrees police officers would argue that their work is more dangerous about of the rank and file officers are attacked each year according to the police federation the royal college of nursing rcn does not have accurate statistics but thinks violence against its members is growing derek ramsay who served in the metropolitan police for four years before becoming a nurse nine years ago says nursing is more dangerous if i was caught in a fight as a police officer i would have top blokes helping me in two minutesin nursing you are alone most hospital security services are useless other arguments however hold more sway shortages of police officers their willingness to threaten action their greater political clout and the reluctance of politicians and unions to address the occupational segregation issue nursing is seen as a vocation but policing is vital to governments which are happy to pay to ensure loyalty during national crises such as strikes that threaten the economy alastair hatchett of ids highlights supply and demand as a basic factor in setting salaries in the case of police officers they have had to pay salaries of that order to attract people in furthermore once they are in the service officers are far more likely than nurses to demand better conditions as they are doing now the police can retire on full pensions at while most nurses must wait a decade longer for less says actuary bryn davies nick page of the cipd says men are more likely to go on strike kick up a fuss and dominate the board ramsay highlights this as the biggest reason nurses dont resist when things happen to them they wont go on strike nursing is not a very united workforce and it is cheaper for politicians to pay more to about police officers than to nurses what is surprising is the unwillingness of the tuc to discuss this apparently for fear of losing friends in one camp or the other and the rcn while urging parity with the police in some of its campaigns is reluctant to comment further a spokeswoman says the police are earning a little bit more we do not comment on what other professions pay you could get into a situation where public sector workers are slagging each other off while the issue is not discussed it may never be resolved the governments women and equality unit does little to highlight the problem despite being committed to reducing the pay gap politicians run a mile from this issue particularly labour ones who fear that in paying police more than nurses they may be seen as keener on the repressive side of government than the caring one if it is genuinely committed to reducing the gender gap however the government must ask itself why the gap is so commission impossible to say the relatively low pay of nurses is indicative of the way this country values what is traditionally seen as womens work other countries value nurses more in australia they jobs richard towers director of the low pay unit no police officers being paid more than nurses says more about the historical gender divisions in the labour market than about the value of the work such differences will stay until we get rid of artificial divisions in our thinking about jobs and focus on skill risk and value will hutton chief executive industrial society the justification for a the commons yesterday we must ensure that women can have confidence that the criminal justice system will take rape allegations seriously and prosecute them effectively and that offenders and potential offenders must know that they cant get away with it ms harman also suggested that a large rise in the numbers of female barristers and senior judges was needed to improve womens confidence in the system the report by the inspectorate of constabulary and the crown prosecution service inspectorate found that of cases examined attackers were charged or cautioned in just from a snapshot of known in the us where it is estimated that m girls and parents take part each year the day has featured in the plot of hit animated film monsters inc as well as in er and spin city on this years day especially encouraged to allow their employees daughters to come in as the figures for girls entering this profession are still low even after years of promotion there has been a increase in the text: it has been the cause of countless arguments across the land and now the truth is finally out women do spend inordinate amounts of time getting ready to go out whether to the office the nightclub or even the shops new research shows it is impossible for a woman to take less than minutes to leave the house regardless of where she is going a survey of women by marks amp spencer has found that the average woman takes the equivalent of working days a year getting ready for work although that is down by two full days on a decade ago it still accounts for minutes a day and per cent of women admit to taking more than an hour the gender revolution has received a great deal of attention in the past few years with women reaching several important milestones in terms of their economic educational and professional power said william nelson an analyst at the future foundation which undertook the research but this shows that despite all their other accomplishments women are still acutely concerned that they will be judged on their appearance the majority of women take minutes and per cent spend over an hour getting ready for a shopping trip the anxiety grows as night draws nearer with the average woman spending minutes preparing for a night out with the girls while a romantic evening demands minutes of care and attention one of the most surprising findings of the research was that women care more about what their female colleagues are thinking and saying about them than their male colleagues scott said while nine out of women claimed their own opinion was most important to them when it came to their appearance at work per cent said the opinion of their female colleagues was most important compared with per cent who gave a fig what men in their office thought this finding certainly suggests women tend to be more conscious of the social rather than sexual implications of their appearance in the workplace scott saidbut when you look around you at the appearance of both sexes nelson said you do have to sometimes wonder whether men should not take a leaf out of their partners book instead of complaining ameliahillobservercouk

text: applause from the labour benches during gordon browns budget speech was prompted not only by the huge investment in health but also by more money for childcare a decade ago even a mention of the cword would have been unthinkable in a chancellor in five years labour has travelled far in putting childcare on the public agenda working parents on lower incomes now get help towards childcare costs new nurseries are to open in deprived areas and a national target of a million new childcare places by has been set the budget extended eligibility for childcare credits to families employing registered childminders in their own homes and to families on higher incomes childcare is now undeniably in the public domain the problem is that responsibility for finding and funding that care remains primarily within the private sphere the government will give you money to help subsidise your childcare but supply has failed to grow to meet parents needs last year there was only one childcare place for every seven children under eight and the government looks unlikely to hit its goal of one million new places whether you can find care for your baby still depends on where you live and how much money you have a nursery place costs on average a week and even those entitled to the maximum childcare credit must still pay of costs ironically in the light of mr browns keenness to see mothers return to work the expense and shortage of childcare is a barrier to womens employment even where the government has provided startup money to create new nursery places in deprived areas it involves a complex web of grants with none guaranteed for more than three years the market has not provided the answer to the uks depressing combination of scarce and costly childcare campaigners agree that without a core of sustained public funding universal childcare will never happen the state need not provide the care it could be the voluntary or private sector but money is needed for may not even be published failing to open a debate would be wrong the country needs to decide whether childcare is a public good or a private problem

text: only one in women reporting a rape will see their assailant convicted according to figures today from the first british study to look at the investigation and prosecution of rape from start to finish the report produced jointly by the inspectorates for the police and the crown prosecution services finds failures throughout the system and calls for a package of measures to bring more rapists to justice among key recommendations are more sensitive treatment of rape complainants to increase their confidence in the system and specialist teams of prosecutors to handle rape cases the report found that of cases reported to police ended up with a conviction the findings confirm home office statistics showing that the rate of conviction for rape has fallen from of reported cases in to in the study of police forces and cps areas found that only of cases reported to police resulted in criminal proceedings or caution and only of the cases referred to the cps reached court where cases reached court the conviction rate including guilty pleas was but seven out of defendants who pleaded not guilty were acquitted in a quarter of cases the complainant withdrew the allegation the report highlights a catalogue of serious failings in the way victims are treated at every step of the criminal justice system its not perfect at any stage of the process it all needs tightening up and sharpening said the inspector of constabulary david blakey who called for a major cultural shift key findings include the sensitive treatment of victims is key to the prospects of securing a conviction better training and guidance are needed for police forensic medical examiners and prosecutors all allegations of rape should be reviewed by prosecutors with specialist training in the handling of sexual offences major review decisions by cps lawyers such as dropping a case or reducing a charge should be discussed with another specialist lawyer to make sure cases are pre sented in the best possible way there should be early meetings between prosecuting counsel and the cps team and the same counsel should deal with the case throughout prosecuting counsel should be more robust to ensure victims are not forced to endure inappropriate questioning in court stephen wooler chief inspector at the cps inspectorate said what we see is the potential for a lot of improvement across the whole process taken collectively these recommendations have the potential to make the pro portion of successful outcomes significantly higher he said the figures were quite disturbing in relation to what is such an awful crime there being few crimes which have such a lasting effect on their victims a crucial element in improving the success rate was making sure victims were well supported from the beginning so they have the courage to go through what they perceive as a substantial ordeal he said probably the biggest single factor is ensuring victims have confidence in the system at all stages a high number of com plaints are subsequently withdrawn by the victim particularly where the victim is known to the assailant factors thought to contribute to the fall in conviction rates include the decreasing proportion of stranger rapes and the increase in cases where defendant and complainant know each other these cases often raise difficult issues of consent another factor is the rise in cases involving drugs or alcohol the report says in themselves the numbers appear shocking the steps we have outlined will we hope have a cumulative effect upon improving the quality of the evidence and presentation in court the impact of this should be to reduce the attrition rate at each stage a spokeswoman for the rape crisis federation said many of these points about treatment of victims and the failures of the criminal justice system are what we have been saying for years we particularly welcome the recommendation for specialist lawyers which led to a conviction rate when introduced in new york
