text: many moons ago when the old boy network dominated the workplace replacing a pompous pinstriped male boss with an empathic and understanding female one would have merely been a pipe dream but years on as women are steadily filling senior management positions and exuding positive professional qualities statistics appear to suggest that many of us would prefer to work for a man in a report produced for the chartered institute of management cim by online recruiters gojobsitecouk of the women surveyed say they would rather be managed by a man while only feel women make better bosses but the bosss gender was irrelevant to most of the women and men surveyed nearly half of women and of men didnt state a preference one woman who certainly does have a preference is danielle hine a pa for a womens glossy magazine give me a female boss any day she says ive worked for male bosses in the past both in australia and london and found them really arrogant we didnt get along very well because im just not the type of girl who would giggle at their silly jokes or pander to their egos in my experience female bosses tend to be much more willing to give their staff extra responsibility and encouragement because they understand the glass ceiling thing and are more likely to push you forward than a male boss so can we believe surveys when they say that we would rather work for a male manager cary cooper professor of organisational psychology at the university of manchesters institute of science and technology thinks not he discounts such results and supports the argument that women make better managers its true that those first women who pushed through the glass ceiling had quite a harsh approach a sort of queen bee attitude but the next generation didnt bother accommodating the male way and allowed their own natural management style to shine through women are often wrongly criticised for being emotionally imbalanced and therefore incapable of having senior management roles men lose their rag at work too they get angry and aggressive and often resort to bullying tactics but due to the experience women have in organising their social or family lives they are so much more adept at being able to hold down a highflying career and deal with the domestic side of life he says the other advantage is that women are sensitive to employees needs which is especially helpful in dealing with workplace change the more women there are handling it the better adds professor cooper furthermore figures earlier this year in the journal people management reveal that feminine management skills are considered more effective than masculine ones john albanmetcalfe is a lecturer in psychology and beverly alimometcalfe is professor of leadership studies both at the university of leeds as part of their research into leadership they asked managers in both the public and private sector to assess a current or previous boss and then identify their sex although the results show that qualities such as vision charisma and inspiration are crucial to leaders at the top the qualities staff value and appreciate in the managers they work with on a close or daily basis are often very different the key attributes are genuine concern for others humour integrity motivating people and responding sensitively to signs of stress and in this study women scored far higher than men but leadership is not about being a wonderman or woman it is about being a decent human being who truly values the individuality of staff and who removes barriers between individuals teams functions and other organisations to work towards the achievement of a joint vision says professor alimometcalfe rather than having a heroic masculine leader our study proved that staff value a caring and encouraging one who helps them to think laterally and motivates them she says that said a lot depends on the individual there are plenty of sensi tive male bosses around just as there are tyrannical female ones there are also people for whom a female boss is their worst nightmare this is the case for jane thomas a secretarial temp in london thomas specifically requests her agency to put her forward for jobs where she will be working for a man because she has experienced too many irrational and difficult women in the workplace one particular female boss used to slam doors and make snide and nasty comments if i so much as said good morning to her she says another would throw dictaphone tapes at me i prefer working for a male boss because i like a direct and cleancut working approach and there arent any feelings of competitiveness but it has to be said that such behaviour could come from either gender perhaps we havent become used to working for women yet and this may be true in some sectors more than others says jackie jones human resources director at gojobsite and she adds women may prefer a male boss because he is less likely to ask personal questions petra cook is head of policy at the chartered institute of management she says that women in management roles simply dont have the time to be nosy and are far more concerned with doing their jobs than finding out every last piece of information about their employees but in any case forming close working relationships with staff is good because it ensures that subordinates are known as people rather than numbers richard tidsall a marketing consultant from richmond has a balanced view towards the boss gender debate i respect people with business flair regardless of whether theyre male or female id probably feel more able to turn to a female boss with a personal issue as they are more understanding and sympathetic but on the other hand a male boss has the ability to be more impartial toni henvest a pa who works for a london law firm agrees she has worked for both good and bad male and female bosses but believes there is nothing worse than a woman trying desperately to make an advisory panel said judges seemed to have been passing lesser sentences where the rapist and his victim were known to each other although this was not a mitigating factor under current rape guidelines which date back to the panel mainly academics judges and magistrates was set up four years ago to provide independent advice to the appeal court judges on the guidelines they should issue to judges in the lower courts to ensure consistency the panels chairman professor martin wasik said sentencing practice does appear to be more lenient when the victim and offender were known to each other it seemed clear to us from the outset that the relevance if any of a relationship between victim and offender was a factor that could not simply be ignored in new sentencing guidelines for rape a research report commissioned by the panel showed that rape was always seen as a very serious crime and that the impact on the victim was as great regardless of the individuals relationship with the rapist our advice to the court of appeal is that new guidelines should include a clear statement that relationship rape and acquaintance rape are to be treated by sentencers as being no less serious offences the solicitor general harriet harman unveiling plans for legislation and proposals for a review of the way courts and other agencies deal with domestic violence yesterday promised a culture change in which any lingering acceptability of domestic violence would be banished between a quarter and a third of murders of women are committed by present or expartners and domestic violence accounts for almost a quarter of violent crime the proposals announced yesterday at a conference of prosecutors in london represent an attempt by ms harman a former minister for women to kickstart the governments stalled drive to tackle domestic violence introduced three years ago the minister has already intervened successfully over an excessively lenient sentence for domestic assault and promised to continue to exercise her powers of appeal among the expected new measures are the introduction of restraining orders which courts could impose during sentencing to ensure violent men stayed away text: an overhaul of britains laws on sex crimes that is expected to sweep away the remaining victorian bans on gay sex and reform the law on rape will be introduced into parliament this autumn the home secretary david blunkett said yesterday we will legislate in the next session of parliament on sex offences and sex offenders sex offences in terms of the th century laws and definitions which have been consulted on in the last two years and sex offenders in terms of updating our laws to take account of the most horrendous events that have been in the headlines in this country the package is expected to include a new crime of adult sexual activity with a child the first of its kind anywhere in the world which will spell out that some cases of child abuse and paedophilia are so serious that they will in future carry a life sentence home office ministers also want to use a sexual offences bill to strengthen the law on rape to tackle the appallingly low conviction rate it will cover issues such as a new definition of consent but will not create a lesser offence of date rape which ministers say is just as traumatic as being raped by a stranger the definition of rape is expected to be extended to include oral penetration mr blunkett said yesterday that he was in the process of finalising proposals to update the centuries old outdated law on sex offences we are balancing here the toughening of protection particularly for children while ensuring the law is fair and nondiscriminatory and reflects the st rather than the th century view of social policy a government white paper setting out mr blunketts proposals is to be published this autumn based on the home office review setting the boundaries which was produced in and has attracted more than responses it will also include proposals to tighten the way the sex offenders register works setting the boundaries advocated sweeping away the remaining victorian offences of gross indecency buggery and soliciting by men which is sometimes called cottaging its author betty moxon argued that the assumption in the original criminal law amendment act that such gay sex acts by consenting adults in private were unnatural legitimised prejudice and contributed to homophobia oscar wilde was jailed under this law the review said that the law which had been used against thousands of men for cottaging or cruising should be scrapped arguing that similar behaviour between men and women would be seen as no more than chatting up the overhaul of the sex crime laws will also include legislation to ensure that incest covers stepparents and keeps pace with the changing nature of the family a new crime of adult sexual activity with a child would replace seven different offences which are currently used to prosecute in child abuse cases which carry different age limits and penalties it is also expected to include heavy penalties for those who engage in the commercial sexual exploitation of children simon hughes the liberal democrats home office spokesman welcomed the decision to bring forward wholesale reform partial reform will not be sufficient and it is right that the government wishes to take more time and get these outdated laws reformed properly he said

text: in the spirit of national selfexamination which swept the country last week the equal opportunities commission has investigated how womens role in the workplace has changed over the past years some of the changes have been sweeping most notably on the upper rungs of the career ladder for example women now make up of professions such as law and accountancy years ago only were women this change could not have come about without an enormous increase in higher education since entry to these professions is restricted to graduates women now make up more than half of those on degree courses compared with just under a quarter in that year only of school leavers went on to university this means that the population of universityeducated women has soared rather than doubled yet surprisingly the office workplace is more highly gendered than it was in back then women made up of the clerical and administrative workforce now the figure is the secretarial agencies insist that the number of men in the sector is increasing and indeed the pendulum may be swinging back to where things were years ago a few years ago men made up of the clerical workforce compared to the figure published by the the eoc last week numbers aside there is also the question of how the quality of life has changed for clerical workers the advent of the personal computer is said to have finished the monotony of the typing pool and broken up secretarial work into specialisations some which are quite lucrative such as document production in law firms yet as it raises expectations of productivity many workers remain as immobile at their desks as secretaries did in the typing pool days and while secretarial workers now have more independence in their work this responsibility can be accompanied by the expectation that they will skip lunch hours to keep up like truth itself progress is rarely pure and never simple

new mother can expect to lose dad will have to give up hours of leisure time in pubs and restaurants during the first years of his childs life but mum will miss out on almost hours of fun researcher dr jonathan scales said the big picture is that parenthood has a significantly different impact for men and women women often have to make radical changes in how they use their time because they text: although it might sound an odd combination gender and development the two are more closely linked than you might think as a lack of equality for women is one of the reasons why the developing world isnt changing fast enough i became interested in feminist theory while studying a languages degree at nottingham and always thought i would pursue it later on after leaving university i spent a year in tanzania as a volunteer working with street children and it was this experience that spawned my interest in the developing world the course at hull offered both undoubtedly one of the best things about it was that we were able to influence its content although there were other students on gender courses there were only three of us doing the development option which gave us incredible freedom alongside lectures in the gender theories poststructural feminist theory queer theory etc we studied allied areas such as the impact of aids a good example of where the subjects cross over would be the plight of women subsistence farmers in tanzania they are not allowed to own land which stops them from obtaining credit a change in the law would allow them to develop their operations and improve their lives dramatically while i was in africa and once i had learnt enough swahili i started to interview the children i was working with and returned with a huge amount of raw data that i had hoped to use for my dissertation however i was persuaded by my tutors that i had a very unusual resource and that it was probably worthy of a phd today i lead three different lives and its all very confusing i have now started the phd which will hopefully make greater use of the tanzanian experiences i am also helping to evaluate the success of youth projects around the country for a report being compiled by the social policy unit at hull and working as an editorial assistant for oxfams inhouse magazine here in oxford almost by default i have become a bit of an expert on focus groups and associated research this week ive been asking children in gateshead to talk about the youth projects they have been involved in in the past ive interviewed women living in poor areas of the uk to describe their experiences for research into social exclusion my goal is to work fulltime for an organisation such as oxfam and to continue looking at the role of women in developing societies im definitely returning to tanzania to continue my phd research ill have to see where it leads me milesbrignallblueyondercouk

families go though were lucky in many respects we both work from home and with luck there will be stretches between setting up the crazy daisy dropping them at friends houses and feeding them plates break the choice is often between taking up to six weeks off and losing your income if your employer will let you and you can afford it or paying for childcare which rises rapidly in cost the more children you have and then all those educational activity weeks and visits to theme parks are guaranteed to drive another large dent in your bank balance anne longfield chief executive of charity kids club network says it can be a nightmare for working parents the majority will be juggling to look after their kids relying to some extent on family members partially on using their own holiday text: a new generation of overs are spurning the tradition of leaving money for their children to inherit and are instead spending it on living the high life nearly threequarters of retirees surveyed by insurer eagle star were happy to spend all their savings on having fun in their later years rather than putting it towards their offsprings inheritance just per cent of men put anything away for their children at all the new youngatheart retirees are using savings to socialise shop and travel nearly a third of those over the age of and per cent of those over admitted travelling frequently i spent my youth bringing up four children and now i would like to do the sort of things i thought i would do when i was a teenager before things took a different path said virginia johnson a former child and family court adviser in derby johnson is planning to spend the equity in her midlands cottage on her adventures now my children are no longer dependant on me im free to live life to the full and really spread my wings she said she recently trekked across malaysia and crete and socialises at least three times a week i dont think my children want me to leave my money to them i have worked hard to help them create their own independent successful lives and now they are happy and settled i want to enjoy myself she said i consider myself still young at and envisage travelling and enjoying myself to the full until im well into my eighties i have some ideas about my pension but im thinking first and foremost about this next stage in my life the survey found that more than one in overs socialised three or more nights a week while overall the retired population spent an average of a month on cars on nights on the town and on grandchildren women aged over spent almost a month on their hair and a month on clothes men in the same age group spent at least a month on clothes and almost a month on keeping fit phil ost of eagle star believes there has been a seismic shift in peoples text: the government through its spending review has taken a major step towards ending the childcare lottery in britain substantial investment in childrens centres is coupled with a new vision for childcare and early years services over the next decade this vision has been prompted by a fundamental cross cutting review of childcare clearly the childcare market isnt working particularly for families living in the most disadvantaged areas the childcare lottery currently means that access to services depends on where families live their income and their employment there is only one childcare place for every seven children under the age of eight and british parents pay the highest childcare bills in europe the interdepartmental childcare review has emphasised the importance of childcare to extending employment opportunities and tackling child poverty childcare also plays a role in meeting other key objectives including boosting productivity and closing the gender pay gap the findings of the childcare review will be published this autumn the review highlights significant benefits to children particularly young children and those from disadvantaged backgrounds when good quality childcare is delivered alongside early years education family support and health services it also points to the need to transform the way in which policy is made and services are delivered to reflect an integrated approach in response the government has decided to bring together responsibility for childcare early years and sure start within a single interdepartmental unit in support of the vision and the review the budget for the new unit will rise to bn by and within this funding for childcare will more than double in real terms between and this will ensure the creation of at least childcare places by including childcare provided directly in childrens centres new funding will be directed towards sustaining provision in the most disadvantaged areas and will support the growth of full day care and out of school clubs and provide grants for new childminders support the creation and operation of childrens centres in disadvantaged areas building where possible on sure start facilities and other existing provision by march an additional children will have access to health education and other services this will complement the greater role that schools will be able to play following the education bill as a base for wider community and family services including childcare for older children as well as joining up existing services and merging the relevant units nationally the government also intends to simplify funding arrangements streamline targets and enhance local authorities role in supporting delivery once the dust has settled we will be able to assess what more needs to be done to turn the vision into reality we must listen to what families say they want in their community to help parents work and give children the support they need an expansion of integrated services through childrens centres will help to address the childcare lottery and achieve wider government policy aims the increased funding is crucial not just to create new childcare but also to support existing services in disadvantaged areas the review of childcare has provided a once in a lifetime opportunity to set a vision for childcare for all children and parents who want and need it the government has seized the opportunity so that we can begin to catch up with the rest of europe now the ambition and extra resources must be turned into a better future for all children and families stephen burke is director of daycare trust

text: take the dingy lift behind the bakery in edmonton greens shopping mall and the doors open on to a bright new world of pink walls and primarycoloured toys the view from the third floor window takes in a concrete multistorey and beyond the tower blocks of the most deprived area of the otherwise relatively affluent borough of enfield but the walls inside are papered with childrens paintings of glorious seascapes this is the new home of sure start edmonton one of almost schemes in an ambitious national programme aimed at boosting the health education and life chances of young children living in poverty the idea is to bring together diverse services and agencies who might never otherwise talk a total of partners in enfield ranging from the council and health authority to libraries and wonmens groups to ensure smooth coordination towards common goals as well as creating a physical resource centre for parents and children to attend as with all sure start projects edmontons targets families with children from before birth to their fourth birthday who live in a closely defined area qualifying because of high levels of deprivation support includes everything from parenting help and breast feeding support to speech therapy and nutritional advice today a handful of the or more children in the schemes catchment area are playing in the creche while their mothers or carers munch sandwiches and discuss where they want the project to go a prime aim of sure start is to involve families through the programme in helping their communities move out of poverty and the mums are proving that ministers wellmeaning vision of empowerment will not always be met with unqualified gratitude why they wonder should their readiness to offer their time for tasks such as helping interview new childcare workers go unpaid according to whitehall rules edmonton project managers are investigating rewarding them with childcare or training courses government plans that the year sure start programme should ultimately shift towards community control and fundraising is met not with happy optimism at the ownership offered by wellmeaning ministers but with frustration at the prospect of withdrawal of newly granted help pares panayi whose threeyear old son georgio loves coming to play sessions at the well equipped centre told the meeting they the government give you this money get you started get you all enthusiastic then we are left to go out with the begging bowl if something is going well why shouldnt they carry on funding it and supporting it childminder terri panteli urged an extension of sure start parents meetings and childrens events to evenings and weekends pointing out that parents working full time such as her own employers were otherwise excluded colleen stirling the programmes community development coordinator reassured parents the project wanted them to have a sometimes uncomfortable debate over its progress sure start was nothing without parental involvement and an evaluation commissioned by the edmonton scheme from anglia polytechnic university highlighted the considerable amount of work that partnerships need to do in order to involve and sustain families as active participants in the management and development of a programme the study also found that while families involved with the scheme were happy with the services they used parenting classes the playgroup the language classes supporting the areas ethnic population and the friendship offered they wanted it to help tackle problems with housing lack of play space and difficulty dealing with the council or health service for the programme manager laxmi jamdagni such local responses must be taken on board and parental involvement nurtured while also working towards a rigid set of targets already laid down by the government for all sure start projects the goals range from the broad including ensuring all children covered by the scheme had access to good quality play and learning opportunities and guaranteeing help for postnatal depression to the highly specific such as a cut by in the number of children reregistered on the child protection register within months or a cut in the number of mothers who smoke in pregnancy edmonton like all sure starts must deliver a quarterly report to the sure start unit in the department for education and skills highlighting progress as well as a monthly form detailing numbers of children pregnant mothers and families seen in july children had contact with the programme approaching half of them new faces together with out of the new babies born in the area within the previous two months the targets ms jamdagni said were top priority now that the project had emerged from a slow start and a struggle to secure its new centre launched in june with a celebration meeting the goals would be a supreme challenge she admitted the government targets are very specific and detailed which is horribly frightening if you ask me are we meeting them i say we are aware of them they are challenging we are listening to parents to make the services fit them better but how we measure the progress is also what we are needing to be mindful of addressing targets means in some cases starting from scratch where basic data is simply not available levels of postnatal depression for example have never been accurately quantified and doing so may be difficult in an ethnically diverse area where different cultures might not name the problem in the same way the partner services will also have to do more to share their information overcoming obstacles such as the fact that many are run by staff on part time contracts who have had little or no contact with each other a further hurdle will be the national shortage of some expertise paula sobiechowska one of the anglia polytechnic university evaluators acknowledged that sure starts targetdriven approach meant a lot of number crunching but argued that the focus on health and poverty was positive and sensible the challenge she said was making sense of the targets where there may be pressures greater than those they identify not least the needs of edmontons transient population of asylum seekers while edmonton has some way to go in matching the governments detailed demands those involved acknowledged that some of the schemes greatest strengths would always lie in a human dimension impossible to measure from whitehall

text: in the pandas class at salcombe preschool in an elegant town house in enfield threeyearolds in painting aprons toss mounds of tornup paper in the air its raining explains one wouldbe meteorologist over in enfield councils civic centre those in charge of childcare and early years education from birth to school entry at four must sometimes also feel themselves awash with showers of paper the department for education and skills set the borough detailed targets to increase availability of childcare and nurseries raise standards in both and ensure all children have access regardless of background the borough is only one of the local education auhorities around the country trying to make it work at a time when even an internal government report on childcare said that its policies were not producing the ambitious increase in high quality places ministers wanted leading to promises of more cash in gordon browns spending review enfield scores highly on quality leading the field in free training for childminders and nursery staff and is on course to attain its departmental goal of a free nursery place for of threeyearolds by are covered so far with poorest areas targeted first however it is wide of the mark on its target of more childcare places by adrift overall and more than off in preschool childminding one childminder terri pantelli told of six or seven calls a week from parents desperate for childcare enfield has also been hit hard by the requirement for the schools inspectorate ofsted to register new childcare and childminders the enormous task is leading to delays of a year or more with childminders waiting for registration places ready to start and only one ofsted inspector allocated to enfield with a long wait in prospect some wouldbe childminders may give up neil rousell assistant director of education is frustrated but argued that the government had given an overlooked corner of education an unprecedented profile the proliferation of targets he warned needed rationalising and the range of grants and funding together with a shakeup of local education authority funding due in april could make strategic planning difficult but mr rousell said enfields early years development and childcare partnership a planning group required in all authorities had proved an effective clearing house for funds we are lean and mean he said with pride we bring people together to squeeze the most places out of every type of provision as so often childcare and preschooling varies according to location in the divided borough historically it had comparatively few preschools attached to schools and they are thus heavily oversubscribed to hit its nursery target enfield will look mainly to private nurseries that are well permitting gillie christou coordinator of home start a scheme supporting women and children said they needed more places but also ones that families on low incomes could afford back at salcombe text: ministers yesterday faced accusations of indecision and bungling amid claims of signficant further delays to the introduction of a computer system at the child support agency poverty campaigners also warned that the continued postponement of the launch scheduled for april this year and now reported to be held up until as late as next summer was depriving children of low income single parent families of sums of up to a week the m system designed to operate a new maintenance formula to simplify and accelerate decisions on support payments by absent parents was developed by a private consortium under the governments private finance initiative the department of work and pensions yesterday declined to comment on reports that work on the system had run at least m over budget or to confirm whether the taxpayer would ultimately have to foot the bill a spokesman said only that the department would not pay the contractor the american computer giant eds until the system had been delivered tested and made fully operational the department also refused to comment on claims by project insiders to the bbc that a new deadline for the systems introduction planned for this november was set to be missed by about six months alistair darling then work and pensions secretary announced in march that he had ordered a delay in the planned launch of the system because testing was not complete the department and the csa yesterday said testing was continuing the agency has million cases on its books while critics will question why eds failed to complete testing of the system in time for the april start date the company yesterday threw the responsibility back on ministers it is completely a ministerial decision about the time frame so that is not eds said a company spokeswoman as for the system there is nothing wrong with it but it is just going through rigorous testing the shadow social security secretary david willetts said that if eds had failed to deliver on its side of the contract it should pick up the bill but he told bbc radio s today programme i suspect that they eds will respond and say that part of the problem at least has been that they have had to wait too long to get clear ministerial decisions on the details of the system before they could go away and write their software in that case sadly it will be the taxpayer who picks up the bill for ministerial mistakes steve webb the liberal democrat work and pensions spokesman said this is the latest in a series of computer bungling by the government in general and the department of work and pensions in particular they seem incapable of running this large scale computer programme either to budget or schedule as a result the families involved with the csa are in complete limbo the gmb union said the delay highlighted the dangers of private finance projects vehemently opposed by trade unions which merely put money in fat cats pockets the child poverty action group warned that delays into next summer would be stretching patience and credulity director martin barnes said every weeks delay means that children in the poorest families receiving income support are losing up to a week

text: childrens social backgrounds are more important even than low birthweight in determining how well they achieve in school and later life according to researchers the study published in this weeks british medical journal firmly points at social deprivation and poverty as some of the most significant reasons why some children do less well than others it finds that low birthweight because of premature birth or a poorly nourished mother does affect intellectual development but this effect is not so great as social class barbara jefferis a research fellow at the institute of child health in london believes the study shows the need for more effort in tackling childhood deprivation these results show the strong effect of social background on cognitive development and the need to take seriously policies addressing deprivation in children she and her colleagues studied nearly children born from march to maths reading and other ability tests measured the educational attainment of the children at ages seven and at the age of their highest educational achievement was recorded the team found the gap in educational attainment between children of higher and lower social classes widened as time went on it was greatest by the age of maths scores tended to improve for classes i and ii from the age of seven to while classes iv and v showed a relative decline as time went on maths scores improved for every kilogram of a childs birthweight but differences between children based on birthweight alone were relatively small high birthweight babies born to more deprived families were likely to do less well on average at school than the low birthweight babies of affluent parents ms jefferis said it was difficult to tease out what it was in early life that might hold back children and what part for instance a school could play social background is a simplification of a lot of complex processes she said

text: a witness in an edinburgh rape trial made scottish legal history yesterday by giving evidence and being cross examined as he stood in a courtroom miles away in australia for the first time in scotland a jury at the high court in edinburgh heard from a witness via live video link as he stood in a witness box on the other side of the world ossian macurcin was giving evidence in the trial of bayram cinci a german national now living in london who is accused of raping a swedish woman at a hostel in oban during a backpacking tour of scotland mr macurcin was allowed to give his evidence from queensland australia after telling the court he was afraid of flying and was preparing for a wedding he was sworn in under both scots and queensland law so as to ensure that if there were any problems relating to his evidence the matter could be dealt with by the australian authorities mr macurcin who was the driver on the tour said some of the group including the accused and the swedish woman had been drinking from two bottles of whisky purchased at a distillery after they checked in at the hostel mr macurcin said he found the woman lying on a bed where she had been sick he took her downstairs to a communal shower area and tried to get her to clean herself up mr macurcin told the court cinci attempted to get into the shower cubicle with the woman who was partially dressed cinci then left for the toilet around an hour later he received a call from the hostel manageress telling him the swedish woman had been found in the cubicle i went back to the shower room and i saw the swedish girl was sitting crouched in the corner of the shower with a towel covering her she was quite distressed she was crying she had her knees drawn up to her chin a crown office spokeswoman said legislation enabling evidence to be given via video link had been on the statute books for a number of years but advances in technology which meant a phone line could now be used were likely to mean it would be more commonly used the trial continues

text: the controversial child support agency has written off bn owed by absent parents since it was set up nine years ago while another m was considered possibly uncollectable it was revealed yesterday the figures hidden in a footnote to the agencys annual report came after parliaments financial watchdog the national audit office refused to approve the agencys accounts for the eighth year running because of a legacy of error steve webb the liberal democrat work and pensions spokesman who unearthed the figures called for the agency to be scrapped it is mindboggling that uncollected payments of bn can be simply written off it is time for the government to admit that the csa has been a fiasco from the start and to scrap it he wants responsibility for collecting maintenance handed to the inland revenue which already does much of the csas work while the csa writes off around m of the m it aims to collect each year the inland revenue collects of the cash it is owed according to mr webb running the csa costs around m a year but the service could not function without information provided by the inland revenue csa staff make inquiries to the inland revenue about missing parents each year and another about the earnings of selfemployed parents savings made by switching responsibility to the taxman would be used to fund bonuses for those who agree not to challenge the level of maintenance payments decided by the inland revenue he suggested the move could also overcome horrendous problems threatened by the new computer system being brought in by the csa designed to provide collected by the agency from nonresident parents and of maintenance assessment debts were incorrect another account statement covering m due from nonresident parents contained overstatement errors of m and understate ment errors of m in debts arising from full maintenance assessment sir john said i continue to be concerned at the high level of error in maintenance assessments it is disappointing that the child support reforms aimed at improving the accuracy of maintenance assessments had to be delayed because testing on a new computer system had not been completed the shadow work and pensions secretary david willetts said delay and uncertainty over a promised replacement for the csa was crippling the service the failure to collect the bn is a scandal the government has been promising for text: when laura doohan discovered that she had become a teenage pregnancy statistic at she had already split up with her boyfriend but she decided to have the baby despite her lessthanideal circumstances a strained relationship with her mother meant she could not continue to live at home but she was nervous about moving into council accommodation with a small child instead a very new labour third way presented itself in the shape of a government initiative to end the isolation of unsupported teenage mothers by offering them a place in a new network of motherandbaby hostels the government announced the scheme in an action plan from the social exclusion units teenage pregnancy unit said that all under lone parents unable to live with their families or a partner should by be placed in supervised semiindependent housing with support instead of being offered council tenancies the idea attracted some flak with critics conjuring images of teenage maternity ghettos and warning of further prejudice against an already demonised section of the population but ministers remained committed to the scheme because britains teenage pregnancy rates are the highest in western europe and because many grandmothers are too busy with fulltime jobs to offer the backup once expected of them the housing corporation has so far approved funding for more than units of supported accommodation some newbuild and others refurbishments after inviting bids from housing associations to run the hostels with three of the six pilot projects up and running doohan now and her fivemonthold daughter ruby anais are among the pioneers in this new design for living a halfway house before setting up home on their own two of the first three hostels are in the same road in nottingham the third is in oldham although one of the two in the raleigh street project was formerly a socalled wet hostel for homeless men who drank you would never guess from the colourful furniture and decor the rooms in the handsome redbrick victorian house look more like wellorganised student bedsits doohan and her daughter have their own large light bedroom with en suite bathroom a bed wardrobe microwave kettle and fridgefreezer are provided together with toys donated by the local church they share a lounge kitchen and payphone in the hall with two other teenage mothers and their babies the aim is to enable the girls to acquire childcare budgeting general educational and life skills including birth control in an informal yet supportive environment there is onsite advice from pearl holt the scheme manager and judith hutton a project worker who staff an office in the house in daytime hours during the week and hold weekly oneonone sessions to encourage the girls to set themselves goals there is a cctv camera outside for security and an outofhours emergency number after initial startup costs the project has become selffinancing based on rent receipts and management allowances there is a twoyear limit for each stay but this is flexible and sensitive to differing rates of personal development so that residents will not be moved until they feel ready for independent tenancies this is about helping people to build up their own support networks thats the key says holt im not advocating teenage pregnancy but we are sometimes too negative about them some of these girls have amazing skills next month doohan is beginning a course in media production with the aim of becoming a journalist while ruby is looked after in the college creche at first it was funny telling people i was living in a motherandbaby home she admits i suppose it was the stigma of teenage mums but my friends were fine and its a brilliant safety net of support a fourth pilot to be run by the ekaya housing association is due to open next january in lambeth south london jackie kelly ekayas chief executive says an onsite computer facility will encourage the young mothers to go back into education in order to build for their future there were she admits some nimby objections to the project from locals some people thought we were a battered womens hostel which we are not and that boyfriends would be turning up and causing rows she says in fact we teach social skills about living with your neighbours and being responsible and the teenage mums enjoy the fact that there are other women like them there they dont feel stigmatised and there is peer support although the aims are practical care professionals are concerned that the scheme may be seen as a punitive kneejerk reaction to media hostility towards teenage mothers getting council tenancies the social exclusion unit report was widely seen as a response to the belief that teenage girls deliberately become pregnant to get a flat yet doohans positive experience is an encouraging sign for the policy of going back to the future by reinventing and updating the concept of motherandbaby homes her relationship with her mother has improved a lot she says since she moved into the homefromhome atmosphere of raleigh street where the big issue at the moment is a tentative experiment in allowing overnight visitors twice a week without changing the dynamic of the centre a dilemma all too familiar to the parents of teenagers the journey from sin to support supported housing for mothers and babies has traditionally been run by religious charities which have also operated as adoption and fostering agencies fifty years ago the strict regimes in such homes reflected the stigma then associated with childbirth outside marriage residents slept in dormitories ate communally and went to bible classes each stay was limited to three months with new mothers given six weeks after the birth to decide whether to give up her baby for adoption apart from an assisted passage to australia as a mailorder bride for a lonely sheep farmer willing to take on another mans child the only way that a lone mother could hope to keep her baby without support from a partner or family was to stay in a hostel as a domestic worker her child was looked after in the hostel nursery even as late as the s such homes were demonised as sin bins particularly in ireland and parts of liverpool where unmarried mothers worked in the notorious conventrun magdalen laundries after being forced to give up their children for adoption but by the early s growing public awareness of the scandalous conditions forced the closure of the magdalens these days the catholic church runs a number of motherandbaby homes for unsupported women on more enlightened and sympathetic lines other schemes run by nondenominational religious charities such as the croydonbased christian family concern describe themselves as bedsits rather than homes and have long since dropped any adoption role similar schemes such as the birminghambased edmonds court foyer also provide training education and employment for young mothers these have proved useful models for the governments new approach

text: more than half of employers now provide paid paternity leave compared with just a year ago a survey of employee benefits has revealed today yet employers are not meeting the needs of all parents the virgin money survey suggests as many as of staff feel that a crche at work would be an important benefit while only of employers actually provide one for the third year in a row what most workers really want is for their company to contribute to their pension just under half of companies pay into a scheme for their staff more than did last year as many as of employees rate this as an important perk health insurance too is considered a top perk with of employees saying that they wanted their employer to offer it however only a quarter of firms actually do so and more than half of employees would like the chance to take a career break although only of companies offered this perk according to the survey one reason for the often serious discrepancies between what staff want and what they get is that companies simply dont ask their workers for their opinions more than two thirds of employees said that their employer hadnt asked them what benefits they wanted during the past twelve months

text: britains long working hours are playing havoc with family life according to research today from the joseph rowntree foundation showing most fathers are not at home to spend time with their children at both ends of the working day a study of dualincome families found of mothers and of fathers regularly start work between am and am and a quarter of mothers and of fathers regularly finished work between pm and pm one in three fathers said they routinely worked more than the hour limit set by the european working time directive fathers in professional and managerial jobs worked the longest hours and were least likely to be involved in their childrens care couples often operated a system of shift parenting with one partner looking after the children in the mornings and the other in the evenings time spent together as a couple was the main casualty said the report by the national centre for social research half these families were unable to share at least one family meal on most days of the week a third of the mothers and of the fathers said their job limited the time they could spend reading or playing with their children or helping with homework this compared with of mothers and of fathers who worked between am and pm the study was designed to look into the social consequences of people working atypical hours but the results suggested that dualincome families with both partners working weekdays between am and pm were in a minority one in seven mothers and one in six fathers worked night shifts starting after pm several times a week almost four in mothers and more than half the fathers worked at least one saturday a month a quarter of mothers and just under a third of fathers worked on sunday at least once a month including of mothers and of fathers who worked on both weekend days

text: fathers need to spend more time at home and mothers more time at work according to a review of work practices by a new alliance of campaigning organisations the review calls for a cultural revolution in attitudes to work the price of unequal opportunity at home and at work is that women do most of the childcare and low paid jobs while men are pushed into a longhours work culture that impoverishes their time with their children says the review by the equal opportunities commission the fawcett society and fathers direct the review welcomes initiatives to introduce two weeks paid paternal leave and to extend maternity benefit which take effect in april next year provision of paternity leave gives vital public recognition that men have a caring as well as a breadwinner role the right to have a request for flexible working seriously considered also comes into force next april but the changes still left women as principal carers with their career prospects damaged while fathers were trapped into a breadwinners role by the need to earn more to make up the family income kathrine rake director of the fawcett society said we have got women into the public sphere now we need to get men into the private sphere even where men put in equal hours at home research suggested they did the good jobs childcare and cooking while women were stuck with cleaning and laundry women working full time still earned less per hour than men while british fathers worked the longest hours in the eu fathers who were the sole breadwinners worked the longest hours

text: as we know from the adventures of mary poppins selfappointed carer to the banks children the selection of a nanny need not concern her employers while the fatheremployer is likely to know less than nothing about childcare in general or his own children in particular the mother being a neglectful feminist type like mrs banks who puts ambition before maternal feelings has forfeited any right to impose her own arrangements parents accustomed to controlling their personal lives may have difficulty with this armslength approach many mothers carried away by selfimportance are apt to think that during their absence the desired substitute is someone safe experienced and to them likeable with whom they share at least some ideas about bringing up children with this in mind and in the absence of any police checks on nannies they will begin their first search for a nanny only after the earnest study of books on nannyinterviewing technique which means that potential employees will be subjected to many gruelling hours of supposedly artless interrogation on everything from religious observance blood transfusions to family background work ethic to views on smoking sweets eating disorders and chastisement psychopath the child will be presented for handling is the nanny too formal too kissy strangely awkward it does not help of course if the child for they do occasionally have views should subsequently express a vehement dislike of this stranger for those summoned for a second interview the process becomes yet more intrusive women who are about to hand over their children to an unsupervised individual for nine or hours a day five days a week can be horribly nosy and captious because what they are searching for in return for their money whether they like it or not is a temporary extension of the family i have known a wellqualified candidate be rejected on a whim because of the frequency with which she said bless another had fatally for her chances expressed a preference for homeoepathic remedies over calpol others had blue hair or bo were too fat or too thin too pretty or too ugly too young or too old one who had impeccable references left the bathroom in an augean condition male applicants were lucky to be phoned back before long according to a report last weekend an extension of the race relations act will make such caprice illegal at least where there can be any question of racial discrimination a home office spokeswoman told the observer people will not be able to discriminate when it comes to employing nannies in their own homes in fact they will be able to discriminate like mad against a multitude of candidates against people who are irritating prying bossy thuggish affected pious loud suggestive snobbishnew agey antisemitic stroppy too clever too dim homophobic or anyone they just dont like the look of so long as they are white but in the event that a candidate who for whatever trifling personal reason has failed to appeal at interview should also belong to a different racial group then the act can be invoked and it will be up to an employer to prove that they are not racist if it were to be widely and impartially enforced the legislation could i suppose be a fabulous boost to britains prized tolerance and diversity safely distant from the world of nannyhiring i can see that it might be quite amusing for the daughter of say an agnostic couple of jewish descent to be raised by an orthodox muslim for a butchers child to be fed by a vegan for the child of a lesbian couple to be cared for by a bornagain believer who thinks nothing personal mind that they will burn in hell equally how refreshing it would be for a girl from an ethnic background that discourages any glimpse of female legs to be cared for by a with edwinas confessions woefully deficient in revelations but behind its unappetising title john birts story the harder path turns out to be quite as comical if not more so than his rivals offering as the author points out a superb closeup view of some of the extraordinary people and events that most shaped our era birts biography should also persuade anyone who has ever doubted the truth of aristotles assertion from the hour of their birth some are marked out for subjection others for rule while lesser men from john tusa to brian wenham were already destined to shine birts boots the infant directorgeneral was he points out in his second sentence a big baby weighing in at lbs even before the prodigy could speak the first consequence of my birth was to reunite my mother with her family from then on portents of greatness came thick and fast liverpudlian women competed to wipe his bottom and not just any old women but confident determined and toughened women who between them had survived the depression and two world wars at seven i had my first taste of success i was chosen to be the crown bearer for the rose queen in our ladys church fete in the same year the same year i came first amongst hundreds of entries for the handwriting prize at the formby show encouraged i entered a national handwriting competition organised by the eagle comic naturally the future ruler also excelled in class i did well at our ladys always coming top so much so that he moved up a form which meant that i was among the top few in my new class but i no longer came first but talent will out i day and always felt a thrill of pride when my name duly appeared in the brecon and radnor express per ardua ad astra you begin to understand why when tony blair eventually followed jim callaghans text: it wasnt much more than a week ago that the tories announced an end to their war against single parents this was tactical rather than practical i believe since it is customary for the end of a war to be announced by its winner the tories must have hoped thereby to persuade us that they had won whereas in fact by any measurable scale single parents must have won since its statistically impossible in this country to be less popular than the conservative party principal carers as lone parents are so nonjudgmentally known by the child support agency must have thought they would be given a short while to regroup and maybe hand out a few medals but no a new war has been launched almost immediately this time by the government itself poor carers they must feel like poland in an effort to make things fairer and faster the csa has announced a new scale to calculate the financial input of the nonresident parent the formula which was meant to be introduced in april but will not take effect until some time next year requires the absent parent to pay of his or her income for one child for two and for three this amounts to a cut in payments to single parents of up to but does not affect the ones who live on benefits therefore it is effectively a penalty on being a single parent with a job which is a little bit rich coming from a government that spent so much of its first term trying to get single parents back to work the csas position is that the system needs to be changed because it is unworkable at the moment it has some good evidence to support this claim in august it transpired that the agency had written off bn worth of debt and considered a further m uncollectable sir john bourne the auditor general estimated in july that of the csas maintenance assessments were wrong in other words this is the most comprehensively rubbish finance collection agency this country has ever seen if a lone parent failed at its quotidian duties this woefully it would have its children taken away so the quest for simplification and greater efficiency is understandable but when the end result is to round down the amount owed to the main carer you cant help thinking that behind this fiasco theres prejudice at work try to imagine what would happen if the inland revenue got most peoples tax assessments wrong wrote off vast quantities of its debts because it couldnt be bothered to chase them and then said sod it lets charge them all a bit less and see if that works well it would make the whole business of being taxed a lot more fun and we wouldnt be able to afford a war against iraq but on the downside society would disintegrate and we would all get cholera the decision is absolutely obscure it doesnt benefit the working single parent and ultimately it cannot benefit the government if the employed are to be penalised those on very low incomes will necessarily be forced out of work and back on the dole the only people gaining from this are the absent parents who are in effect being rewarded for the merry bn dance theyve led the csa on since its inception nine years ago of course this is infinitely worse than the nowdefunct tory war it doesnt make any difference to anyone whether or not the opposition party thinks they got pregnant just to get a council flat if anything the act of annoying norman tebbit might add to your overall quality of life the government scheme on the other hand has important and damaging financial ramifications but the thinking behind new labour and old tory is the same single parents are quite simply worth less than other groups they are worth less than dual parents they are worth less than the childless and most ridiculously they are worth less than absent parents their payments are chased less tenaciously than bloody parking fines they were harried back to work with the most patronising of poster campaigns and now they are penalised for being in work the very people who demonstrate their sense of social responsibility most assiduously are the ones who are treated with least respect by their society conceivably this all stems from a moral agenda that still puts some crazy value on marital respectability even though the only people who really stay married for life these days are politicians themselves and thats just because they have such ahem funpacked professional lives possibly there is a misogynist undertone here since though we all strive with modern evenhandedness not to group resident and absent parents by gender the former are still mainly women i wonder though whether it isnt all a bit more pragmatic than that lone parents are notoriously timepoor individuals being so busy with kids and whatnot if youre going to victimise anyone you may as well victimise the ones who dont have time to fight back zoewilliamsntlworldcom

text: a government minister failed to release figures showing that single working mothers could lose an average of over a year under a new child support maintenance system it was revealed yesterday malcolm wicks parliamentary undersecretary at the department of work and pensions hid figures showing that a single working mother with one child would lose nearly of her maintenance income a working mother with two children would lose more than a year instead mr wicks claimed in a written parliamentary answer that the government could not work out firm average figures on losers and winners under a new assessment system the figures are damaging to the governments campaign to get mothers back to work since those staying on benefit and out of work would not lose such large sums the assessment calculations came to light after the liberal democrat works and pensions spokesman stephen webb used the data protection act to obtain confidential advice between the minister and his civil servants on answering a parliamentary question he had tabled to the minister these revealed that mr wicks had been sent a suggested reply revealing both the average child support maintenance assessment under the current system and the percentage changes when the new system comes into force this showed that single mothers would have to have at least three children before they would benefit by an average of a year under the change mr wicks replied it is not possible to make firm estimates of the change to the average payment in child support maintenance as a result of the introduction of the new child support scheme a minute from the civil servant said this is a delicate area we are conscious that we do not wish to draw unnecessary attention to it he added that release of the information may provide mr webb with fresh impetus to debate who will be betterworse off in the new scheme mr webb yesterday described the departments attitude as a cover up he added hardworking single parents text: most working fathers will not take time off to look after their children during half term this week because they think bosses discriminate against men showing any commitment to childcare according to a report today from the work foundation after researching attitudes in the workplace the employment thinktank found a widespread fear among men that sharing equally in parenting responsibilities will lead to career death the foundation said british workplace culture was set by a generation of corporate men in their s who had been supported by wives who stayed at home to raise their children at least in the preschool years they have woken up to the fact that they now employ mothers but few have paid attention to the consequence that this means they now employ a different kind of father the foundation said according to the governments labour force survey of married or cohabiting mothers with preschool children also hold down a job in many families that was forcing men to take on more domestic and caring duties but the implications for men have not yet registered on the corporate radar as a result men are nervous about taking paternity leave or asking for time off for flexible working to help them manage their childcare responsibilities they often prefer to parent by stealth for example using offsite client meetings to cover up for the time they spend looking after the children and avoid appearing uncommitted or less masculine in front of their colleagues richard reeves author of the report said equality at work and equality at home are intertwined until there is a redistribution of unpaid work towards men women will never be able to achieve full parity in the labour market the foundations findings were based on unpublished research by the equal opportunities commission showing that nearly twothirds of firms offered paternity leave but most fathers did not take it the eoc survey found the vast majority of fathers liked paternity leave being unprecedented numbers of offspring in their twenties returning often several times to live with parents for parents the implications of the lifelong parenting trend include potentially a more enduring bond with children but also a longer financial commitment

text: three sparse rooms in a sexual health clinic hardly signal a revolution off a spotless corridor between a waiting room and a shower room is a small cupboard incongruously stocked with hot drink ingredients and surgical robes next door the mix of tea sympathy and forensic science is most stark a kitchenette and a couple of comfy chairs are divided only by a curtain from an austere examining chair for visitors to the haven in camberwell south london the capitals only sexual assault referral centre this mix of science and sympathy is vital in the history of reporting and investigating rape in britain the centre is truly radical gone is the agonising wait often for hours for a forensic doctor in a cold and frequently illmaintained rape suite in a police station where victims are unable to wash drink or urinate so that forensic evidence is preserved gone too is the added ordeal of reporting the details of rape to an officer with no expertise in investigating sexual offences and no special training which has bred the common perception of police attitudes to rape victims as highly sceptical and bullying gone that is for victims who report rape in one of the south london boroughs the treatment of people reporting rape in the rest of the capital remains subject to a postcode lottery with victims at the mercy of varying attitudes and care and unable to get followup treatment advice and counselling in the same place with only three similar models elsewhere in england and wales in newcastle upon tyne manchester and leicester standards in rape investigations nationally are variable but the inequalities in londons service at least are set to be remedied the metropolitan police has brokered a partnership with the nhs jointly to fund similar centres at st marys hospital in west london and the royal london in the east end at a cost of m each the new centres are due to open next april and the use of examination suites in police stations will be phased out the metropolitan police authority met has become so concerned at the relatively small number of convictions in rape cases that it is overhauling its approach in what it calls project sapphire launched last year sapphire is claimed to be the most comprehensive reform of rape investigation ever undertaken by the police reporting of rape is notoriously low prosecutions are lower still and convictions rare the haven is designed to address these issues victims are brought to the centre in unmarked police cars through an unmarked entrance there is only ever one victim in the centre at any one time and to ensure dna evidence is above challenge the centre is cleaned after each victim leaves members of the medical team are specialists in both this area of forensics and the way they question and approach victims the approach balances the criminal investigation with victim care says amanda price the havens manager anyone coming here will know that we take rape very seriously and that were not making any judgments she says we notice how smoothly the process of reporting goes if you have a specialist team the centre generates more awareness and expertise and that generates greater disclosure most victims choose to accept the offer of followup appointments after their initial visit to the centre this is likely to reflect the fact that the process is not intrusive kate armitage a doctor and sexual offences examiner at the haven says we only ask questions that are relevant to the investigation and as far as sexual history goes we only need to know for forensic reasons if a woman has had sex in the previous two weeks though the centre was set up and is funded by the met victims who have learned of it by word of mouth can refer themselves for examination and treatment without having reported the crime forensic evidence can be taken if they should later decide to do so and victims who are considering going to the police can talk informally to an officer at the centre however most of the referrals made since the centre opened in june have been from police officers there remains much more to be done if the met is to improve rape investigation and victim care admits detective sergeant james stokley a member of the sapphire team the project has established dedicated hour sexual offences investigation teams in of the london boroughs averaging six sexual offence investigation soit officers these uniformed but specially trained police arrange a medical and forensic examination and take the victims initial statement stokley compares the role of soit officers to family investigating officers in a murder case or dedicated teams in community safety units investigating hate crimes soit officers should be the only police contacting the haven and accompany a victim to the centre on arrival the officer should explain the case to the doctor to avoid the victim having to repeat the details however some experts are concerned that soit officers may not always be available hours a day and that some victims still have to report to uniformed officers not specialised in dealing with sexual offences as part of sapphire front desk staff in police stations who are often civilians have been trained in how best to talk and respond to rape victims measures are also under way to improve intelligence on rape with a plan to track cases to understand why they fail to reach prosecution or conviction and to target linked sex offences and enhance public awareness of rape through campaigns such as those on minicab rape and drug rape stokley says that sapphire has managed to exceed the mets target of judicial disposal rates when a rape suspect is charged and raised the status of work on the crime sapphire has put rape at the forefront of policing officers take pride in what theyre doing the improvement he says is phenomenal when measured against the notorious tv documentary showing thames valley police bullying a woman who had reported rape the majority of rapes occur within the home stokley stresses stigma and fear inhibit women from coming forward its all about confidence he says theres a perception that people wont be believed or that its their fault we want people to come forward we want the figures of reported rape to go up its not satisfactory that so few women report it liz kelly professor of sexualised violence at london metropolitan university and director of the child and woman abuse studies unit at the university of north london is a member of the police authoritys independent advisory group iag on reporting and investigating rape she says the met is the only police service to have made rape a priority rapes largely dropped off the policy agenda sapphire happened because there are senior met officers who really care about the issue however kelly would still like to see improvements in investigation theyve dealt with the structures for victim support but have not yet done enough to address why cases are being lost before they reach the cps she says they can still make a difference on collecting evidence merlyn nuttall a rape survivor and member of the iag argues that the haven is long overdue but not nearly enough she wants every victim to have access to a centre like the haven its just ludicrous that its a postcode lottery she says there should be no barriers between victims and adequate places for them to go against the odds home office research estimates that one in women has experienced some form of sexual victimisation including rape however only one in victims reports it to the police with fewer than a quarter of allegations resulting in a suspect being charged the odds of a rapist facing a court are one in over the past years there has been a continuing and unbroken increase in reporting to the police but the number of convictions has remained fairly static the biggest proportion of lost cases fall at the earliest stage with between half and twothirds not reaching the point of referral to prosecutors according to research commissioned by the crown prosecution service inspectorate according to this years british crime survey women aged are more likely to say they have been sexually victimised than are older women most rapes take place in the victims own home and women are most likely to be attacked by their partner of cases strangers were responsible for only of rapes reported to the survey

text: britains prosperity will suffer if the government does not come up with new money to help women scientists and engineers back to work after having children a report warned yesterday the report commissioned by the trade and industry secretary patricia hewitt and drawn up by lady greenfield director of the royal institution called for state funding for fellowship schemes to enable women who have taken family career breaks to retrain and update their skills besides traditional problems of sexism women scientists and engineers particularly in academia are vulnerable in the highly competitive fastmoving world of research scientists are judged on the number of research papers they publish in academic journals so taking time out to start a family exposes women to the feared publications gap which counts against them when they try to pick up their careers the number of women getting phds in the biosciences chemistry engineering and technology has risen significantly in the past few years while the number of men has fallen the number of women in science engineering and technology jobs has gone up from to in the past decade but the report found institutional sexism a career system not in tune with families and the glass ceiling remained to block progress particularly at the top level of science if the number of women was just going to drift up we would see more women in senior positions its just not happening said jan peters of the natural environment research council one of the scientists who drew up the report lady greenfield who is also professor of synaptic pharmacology at oxford university said we are past the bottompinching stage its not so much someone being overtly rude to your face as you feeling that people are prejudiced against you its institutional sexism nancy lane of cambridge universitys zoology department said nobodys rude nobodys unkind they simply ignore you she recalled a male professor saying to a female colleague dont you worry your pretty little head about that the report tells the story of a distinguished academic who happened to be the only female member of a senior international science committee in april this year its chairman said she would add some glamour to the discussion even back in almost a half of britains bioscience graduates were women yet women make up only of bioscience professors today suggesting thousands of promising careers have fallen by the wayside another of the reports authors gill samuels a director of science policy at the pharmaceutical company pfizer warned women had to be tacticians in the lab its important women learn how to deal with sexism men may not know they are being offensive they may think its just joshing in a team setting lady greenfield said she expected the government to come up with money to fund the reports recommendations i think they will be obliged to put their money where their mouth is she said ms hewitt said the government would publish its response to the report shortly increasing the number of women scientists and engineers is vital for future uk competitiveness and productivity she said successful british companies increasingly depend on the strength of their scientific and technological expertise and we are obviously missing out on a huge pool of talent
