text: good news about womens pay is rare so it is a welcome change to see a statistic showing women outpacing men the chartered institute of managements annual survey of management salaries reveals that the remuneration of women directors rose by between and and while that of men at a similar level increased by better still statistically at least slightly lower down the hierarchy women managers averaged a increase against mens but these figures may represent a snapshot of how various sectors of the economy are doing rather than a positive social trend the institute itself acknowledges that the discrepancy may be accounted for by the fact that the public sector where the majority of senior women managers work has grown over the past year while the more buccaneering sectors of private enterprise where bluechip boardrooms remain maledominated have had a dismal time more significant still is that over the past two years the culture of city bonuses has withered this has been as a result of the collapse of the boom in mergers and takeovers which dominated the s and drove up the eyewatering bonuses of some financial professionals it was the sometimes blatantly unfair distribution of bonuses rather than inequalities of salary that accounted for women earning less than men in financial institutions and after the public sector the financial sector is the biggest employer of senior women managers another factor is that although manufacturing is in recession the service sector continues to grow senior managers in manufacturing are mostly men while the service sector is more willing to promote women or to be fair has a larger base of women employees from which to find management material while the gap between mens and womens remuneration remains wide at all levels and even average rises of are not enough to see women overtaking men yet the shift of emphasis to service in public and private sectors could help to develop a more level playing field bill saunders

text: britains supposedly loutish lads seem to be fast turning into loving dads as michael owen announced this week that at he will soon follow fellow england star david beckham into the labour ward the only bottle todays young men are reaching for apparently is one with a teat on top this impression is backed up by a new survey on the mating habits of young british males researchers at essex university found that despite an infamous reputation as serial shaggers they are in fact five times more likely than their italian contemporaries to have settled down by so what is happening has the loaded generation gone soft possibly unless we are simply waking up to a longhidden phenomenon celebrity has done a service by casting its limelight on a largely invisible side of fatherhood what michael douglas and david jason reveal about the wrinkly end of the paternal experience michael owen is doing for boy dads the truth is there have always been lots of them its one reason why britain has such a high teenage pregnancy rate six times higher than in the netherlands one statistic is telling a quarter of all young men entering young offender institutions are or are about to become fathers but fatherhood in young men is largely ignored or overlooked because they lack traditional qualifications job home money we dont rate them as dads men like jude though challenge the stereotype of the feckless lad two years ago when he was just jude became fulltime dad to his son rushaun then three months old his girlfriend was no longer around jude from south london had no job no home of his own and no money in the past rushaun might have been adopted yet today he is with his dad who remains out of work and lives in a sparsely furnished council flat as the eldest in his own family jude has advantages im used to caring for my brothers and sisters he says im young so rushaun learns more from me and its easier to be a role model i have my youth and energy i have time to do what rushaun enjoys i can see life growing in him every little advancement but it has not all been easy its taken me two years to get the feel for being a father he admits ive had to look around and take it all in at first i felt like an alien im the oldest of seven so my mum has six others to cope with and cant do that much for us i have to do it by myself powerful celebrity role models such as beckham help young fathers like jude feel less of an alien beckham of course has no problem with the breadwinner bit but his distinguishing characteristic is his public endorsement of caring fatherhood for a young dad perhaps with little else to offer this can be a liberation celestine agbo who has worked with young dads for over years recognises beckhams importance during this years world cup he established a young fathers group i put an advert in the paper for meetings of a david beckham supporters club he recalls i got a few phone calls it turned out that six nearly half the people who rang were young men with children once i asked them about their kids they got really excited about discussing them i think it is because often when young dads get into relationships no one wants them to talk about their kids so it is refreshing for them rushaun is however a lucky child just of teenage fathers remain in touch with the mothers years later it means that children born to a teenage dad this year will not be seeing him by the time they themselves are teenagers does this matter to the child hugely according to recent findings by professor judy dunn at the institute of psychiatry a close relationship between an estranged father and his child is highly beneficial to a childs development particularly when the mother became pregnant as a teenager it is easy to see how it all goes wrong about a third of new dads are reluctant parents reports fatherhood reclaimed by adrienne burgess a survey of found that nearly half had never discussed starting a family with their partners these figures are even higher among younger men and strongly predict relationship breakdown even willing young dads quickly become alienated says celestine agbo he starts out feeling whoa great im a man shes having my baby theres excitement he has romantic ideas about what he and his son they always think it will be a son will do together but gradually he feels redundant she goes back to her mum theyre doing the shopping getting the clothes ready it gets like christmas there is a lot of pressure and his partner may be angry with him he goes on especially if he is not working she may decide she doesnt need him some young dads tell me they have to pay to see their child clearly young mothers cannot be expected to support partners through a transition into fatherhood if there is outside help though it can make a huge difference not only to the mothers and the childs prospects but to the young mans new research from bristol university suggests that young fatherhood far from being problematic can bring young disadvantaged men the very ones who are cropping up repeatedly in crime statistics out of social exclusion as fatherhood confers the status and achievement work once provided lads can turn into dads the bristol study quotes brian when katy became pregnant with jimmy obviously there is still a part of me that thinks like youre young and all that he says but ive got to be prepared not to see my mates and not spend me money at the start of the month and then go skint for the rest with a baby you cant do that youve got to make sure there is enough in the bank so were going to have to grow up pretty quickly but i respect that there is someone going to be calling me daddy you know after the birth life got more difficult with housing and work as i work shifts i cant really help in the evenings as jimmy will be in bed when i get home explains brian so its every other week that i can help out i go over every night and see katy as katy shares a room with jimmy i cant have an alarm clock going off and waking him early because she would have to cope with him once id gone to work its all changed since this new job i used to be able to help with bottles and everything saw him every night then it was nice but the money wasnt there brians story highlights a problem with the way government and society champion a work culture to the detriment of the caring side of fatherhood the state has yet to appreciate the potential of young fathers summed up by michael owens words ive had a few exciting moments in my career but nothing that compares to how i felt when louise told me the news given such enthusiasm why is it according to the bristol research that antenatal staff largely ignore young dads why did half the health visitors interviewed know little or nothing about the young fathers they were meant to support the example of michael owens public excitement may bolster some isolated young men like jude but as long as so many other people and institutions are ambivalent about his role and fail to offer a helping hand that figure of children losing their young dads by their teenage years is unlikely to fall jack osullivan is a cofounder of fathers direct the national information centre on fatherhood wwwfathersdirectcom

text: men accused of rape will no longer be able to get off by arguing that they honestly believed a woman was consenting however unreasonable that belief might have been the government has listened to womens organisations which have campaigned for years for reform of the honest belief defence the defence has been available since when the house of lords ruled in the case of morgan v the director of public prosecutions that a mans genuine belief that the woman was consenting was a defence to a rape charge even if the belief was unreasonable in the circumstances morgan had invited three strangers to have sex with his wife telling them she liked to struggle to get turned on the men were convicted but appealed eventually to the house of lords the convictions were upheld but the lords ruled by a threetwo majority that there could be no rape conviction if a man honestly believed a woman had given her consent and that his belief did not have to be reasonable the honest belief defence was one of the most contentious issues tackled by the interdepartmental working party which recommended farreaching changes to sex offences law in july to the disappointment of many it decided to keep morgan while trying to fetter inappropriate use of honest belief a man would not be able to claim honest belief if he had made himself drunk failed to take all reasonable steps to ascertain that the woman was freely agreeing or was reckless as to whether she was consenting more than half of those responding to the recommendations however wanted to scrap morgan altogether and the government has listened to their voices the white paper proposes that where the prosecution can prove that there is reasonable room for uncertainty about the complainants consent and that the defendant did not take reasonable action in the circumstances to ensure that the complainant was willing to take part in the sexual acts rape will be proved this introduces a new test of reasonableness to be judged by what an objective third party would think in the circumstances in deciding whether the defendant acted reasonably the jury would have to take into account the actions of both parties the circumstances in which they placed themselves and the level of responsibility exercised by both the government hopes to make the issue clear by including in the statute a nonexhaustive list of circumstances in which consent is presumed to be absent where the victim was subjected to force or fear of force threatened or put in fear of serious harm to herself or another person abducted or unlawfully detained unconscious unable to communicate consent because of physical disability or had agreement given by a third party the new law would make it clear that children under were incapable of giving consent to any sexual activity and any sexual activity with someone incapable of consenting because of a learning disability or mental disorder would be an offence

text: yesterdays white paper on sex offences with a bill to follow in the new year passes the first two tests that any legislation should face is is necessary has it been well thought out the answer is yes to both questions there has been no consolidation of sexual offences for years even then the act was mainly a pulltogether of thcentury laws the current law is a patchwork of court rulings old statutes and sudden responses to important reports like wolfenden on the decriminalisation of homosexuality in private in the result is an archaic and contradictory jumble a man who has unlawful sexual intercourse with a girl under faces a twoyear sentence but a man who indecently assaults her without sexual penetration faces years there are different age threshholds time limits and even different offences according to whether a sexual assault is on a boy or girl is it well thoughtout yesterdays white paper is not a kneejerk response to tabloid allegations by ulrika jonsson or anyone else it is the culmination of four years work including a review committee extensive consultation and special conferences that ended with a wellbalanced page document two years ago yesterdays policy paper follows the main thrust of the earlier work it does not seek to intervene in private relationships between consenting adults but it proposes important reforms on rape gay sex and sexual abuse ministers should be congratulated for reforming such sensitive laws which their predecessors did not dare to touch rape social reformers are rightly concerned by the dramatic drop in convictions in the last years from to much of this is probably caused by the rise of date rape ministers have resisted making date rape a lesser charge rightly so since the effects can be as traumatic as stranger rape instead they are tightening the rules that currently allow defendants to plea an honest belief in consent even where this is unreasonable they are widening the law to include penile penetration of the anus and mouth and they reject tabloid pressure to give defendants the same anonymity that victims have rightly been given gay sex here the law was in its most archaic and discriminatory form the review rightly referred to the way in which the laws language unnatural acts and buggery helped to legitimise prejudice and encourage homophobia homosexual and heterosexual activity is to be put on an equal footing homosexuals will no longer be pursued for cruising which in the heterosexual world would be regarded as chatting up but like heterosexuals gays will be prosecuted if they have sex in view of the public or solicit sex in a manner that causes public anxiety sex abuse the rules of the sex offender register which already achieves compliance will be tightened but there will be no sarahs law giving public access to it because that leads to lynch law and offenders going to ground where they can not be monitored there will be new laws with severe penalties for sexually exploiting children for gain or grooming children for sex on internet chat sites one rare omission is the dropping of a proposed persistent sexual abuse act which will rightly cause concern among childrens charities most sexual abuse remains in the home the old incest law however will be widened to include adoptive and step relations it is a good package it got a progressive response from tory mps yesterday but will the archaic house of lords defend archaic laws that is the question

text: two victorian scandals shaped britains sex laws which have remained in place for more than years and under which oscar wilde and john gielgud were prosecuted and thousands of other men are still arrested each year an overhaul of the laws on sexual offences has not been attempted since and even the sexual offences act of that year was a consolidation of the victorian statutes and passed without real debate there has been some reform since then including the decriminalisation of homosexuality in private in changes to the law on rape and increased protection for children but much of the law still dates back to the criminal law amendment act the first scandal was triggered when the crusading journalist wt stead revealed the white slave traffic at the heart of the british empire he was jailed for showing it was possible to buy a yearold girl for sex in london the scandal led to legislation raising the age of consent for girls from to but the bill was ambushed by henry labouchere a republican liberal mp who proposed it should also make any form of sex between men a crime anal sex had been illegal since the reign of henry viii but his amendment extended punishment to any act of gross indecency there was little debate the main concern was that it might become a blackmailers charter and the legislation did not criminalise lesbianism hansard records that when one peer tried to raise the issue he was told to shut up on the grounds that he would only advertise its existence to an impressionable public the new law unleashed a wave of homophobic witchhunts which began with the sensational cleveland street scandal of it was revealed that two peers of the realm lord arthur somerset and lord euston and it was claimed prince eddy the son of the prince of wales had visited a male brothel in london where post office telegram delivery boys were corrupted at four shillings a time the scandal cemented public support for the legislation the trial and imprisonment of oscar wilde for gross indecency followed in amid an intense newspaper campaign against the buggers although the number of offences has fallen there were cases of buggery reported to the police last year cases of gross indecency and cases of soliciting or importuning by a man the police never lost their taste for using these laws to hound the famous gielgud was arrested for cottaging soliciting in a public toilet in the s

text: reports that the government plans to introduce tax relief for working parents who employ nannies have been a little exaggerated they have also caused a division of opinion among the lobby groups who campaign for better childcare provision what is at issue is the claim that fees paid for the childcare of working parents is income that is taxed twice once when the parent earns it and again when the parent takes responsibility for the carers tax and contributions including an employers ni contribution the problem of managing two tax returns for one income is usually confined to professional women who earn enough to be able to employ a domestic nanny rather than using a pooled childminder or if they are lucky a nursery school nevertheless it is a problem that binds them in spirit to all working mothers who resent having to forfeit a substantial chunk of their wages to go to work in the first place when early in the last labour government the chancellor changed the status of workplace creches so they were no longer a taxable benefit there was optimism that the principle had achieved acceptance and hope that tax relief on childcare might follow the governments latest concession text: the spokeswoman from the department for education and skills sounded hurt she was most disappointed that childcare campaigners did not recognise the governments unprecedented commitment this weeks plan from the prime ministers strategy unit certainly boasts some big numbers in bn is being spent on classes for preschoolers childcare for undereights and sure start the programme for deprived children in addition mplus is being spent on tax credits to help parents pay for care labour has already delivered free preschool education for all fouryearolds and ought soon to offer the same for threeyearolds childrens centres offering medical services and family support are due to open in poor districts why then is the government not getting much kudos why was the response of daycare trust and other campaigners this week so curmudgeonly in part the answer is that the government has played fast and loose with the evidence we know little about what is provided where the chart apparently shows welcome expansion one childcare place per children by a huge improvement on s ratio of one per nine children but the projections for and conflate full and parttime places ask a mother working in households especially the lone parents the government is keen to see working outside the home it is not putting up enough money to do the former properly but lacks the political courage just to concentrate on the latter six out of mothers with a child aged under five now have jobs over the past four decades the proportion of men of working age in jobs has fallen while womens paid work has expanded four out of women of working age have dependent children many families as a result face a daily struggle to find someone to look after their children while they are at work families often being a euphemism for mothers the problem is both undersupply of places and high cost reliable and stimulating care takes reasonably paid staff the government is rightly putting a lot into better training but keeps mum about the need to pay childcare workers more before the famously familyfriendly tories did little or nothing childcare was deemed to be a private matter on taking office labour accepted two things one was that state intervention in the lives of poor children could improve their life chances the other was that womens employment was a precondition of prosperity tony blair city academies get on with it free of the targets and tape in which they have been cocooned in childcare the strategy unit promises to give responsibility to local authorities but that is a recipe for big differences between different areas say the campaigners why is the london borough of hackney its population among the most needy closing nurseries the parents who most need help live in areas served by councils with the worst records as part of his efforts to get more lowincome people into lowincome jobs gordon brown conjured up subsidies tax credits intended to pay for childcare but the approach to childcare with what has happened to care of the elderly in the early s twothirds of places in old peoples homes were public sector now seven out of are private sector the supply of places text: noughties woman does well at school goes on to higher education has jobrelated training and is increasingly likely to work fulltime all her life yet the public and private symbols of success the wellpaid job the car even the company pension are still more likely to go to her male contemporary according to research to be released today by the governments equality unit she is more likely to rely on public transport and much more likely to go into clerical work after university she is less likely to take an appointment on a public body stand for election or get into parliament and still earns significantly less than a man the equality units snapshot of key indicators of womens position in britain shows how rapidly their lives are changing in the early years of the st century and how much further they still have to travel if they are to have the same opportunities as men it will provide a benchmark against which policies aimed at narrowing the differences can be judged campaigners hope it will lead to the setting of official targets to close the pay gap which even after years can mean a woman earning little more than half as much as a man girls outstrip boys at every stage at text: the government today paved the way for a hand over of responsibility for its key childcare programmes to local councils with a downing street unit warning that this was the only way for the government to deliver its ambitious promises on poverty the prime ministers strategy unit is calling for the flagship sure start programme in particular to be devolved to local government the programme widely regarded as successful aims to provide child support and development services for children aged under four and their parents in some of the most deprived areas of england the plans to give more power to councils are designed to end the current confusion over who is responsible for delivering childcare and to rationalise the plethora of funding arrangements ministers have put in place the strategy unit report calls on the government to join up its policy by handing more power to local councils it says clarity in the role of the local authority should facilitate the joining together of services and programmes at the local level delivery of the governments vision will also require local authorities over time to extend their remit to take responsibility for delivering sure start programmes currently managed from the centre particularly where such services are being integrated with childcare and early years education on the ground the strategy unit also wants to see the local partnerships of childcare providers councils businesses and regeneration organisations that were set up in to deliver the governments national childcare strategy to be pushed into a secondary role subordinate to councils it complains that accountability for childcare is unclear because the partnerships have no legal status or bank account the report suggests making local government chief executives directly responsible for the sure start scheme the strategy unit report also sets out how the government plans to use the extra money allocated in this years threeyear spending review to deliver at least new childcare places by and to create new childrens centres to provide care family support and health services in one place the prime minister today welcomed the publication the measures detailed in this report represent good news for children giving them a better start in early education and health so that they can increase their potential

text: at last four months after the chancellor gordon brown gave us an outline the detail of the governments longpromised crosscutting review of childcare is now available since july baroness cathy ashton the minister in charge of the new interdepartmental childcare unit in the department of education and skills has had a title but no job the strategy unit report delivering for children and families provides her with a mission except her task turns out to involve handing over childcare to local authorities and effectively ending the pioneering sure start programme for disadvantaged children in rundown areas through its national childcare strategy and various early years and outofschool initiatives the blair government can rightly claim to have put the question of providing for children outside the confines of formal schooling firmly on the policy map it can also claim to be putting serious money into childcare outside the home after in july mr brown added considerably more but the document from the strategy unit which carries the imprimatur of the prime minister himself shows that the government has failed to make up its mind on two critical questions one is about selectivity who is the childcare intended for an option was to create a universal childcare service just as in denmark or france or other european countries there parents at both ends of the income scale expect the state to provide subsidised nursery care somewhere in their locality instead what the blair government seems to have gone for is a service for poorer parents in deprived wards heavy emphasis has been placed especially by mr brown on childcare that will allow single parents to go to work sure start was confined to a strictly delimited number of poor districts the proposed childrens centres will again be available only in areas characterised by low incomes and high social need that is what you might expect a social democratic government to do but there are problems what about poorer parents asks national childcare charity the daycare trust what about poorer parents living in betteroff districts who get missed out and there is a political issue if you provide public services for the betteroff middle classes as well as the poor you are more likely to enlist the sympathy of the middle classes and perhaps make them more likely to pay the necessary taxes to fund the service daycare needs unite mothers across the various income bands worklife balancing acts are possibly more unstable in middle class homes the governments message has been confused does it really expect the private market to take care of all the needs of families above a certain income in the past it has not and probably never could in the future the second question facing labour is how childcare is to be provided sure start was an initiative from the treasury it was centrally planned and operated on templates drawn up by naomi eistenstadt and her colleagues the national childcare strategy was precisely that a central government programme of course it had to be implemented locally but what resulted was a messy set of local agencies some inside the local authority some entirely voluntary the strategy unit report lists the confusing mass of partnership arrangements now along comes the government saying councils are to entirely take over responsibility for childcare including eventually sure start but councils vary tremendously in how much interest they take in preschool and outofschool provision they also vary in their capacity to deliver a nonmainstream programme such as childcare the strategy unit document says little about how much extra money will in future flow to councils through their revenue support grants but if it does not why should they bother with a programme they will say they cannot afford if extra cash does get through some councils will use the money for other purposes more fitting to their local sense of priority the london borough of hackney is closing nurseries adjacent to some of its poorest estates for local financial and political reasons councils will differ in their approaches but does the government really want more diversity in provision of a service that is already patchy the strategy unit report implies that by there will be more than enough childcare places to meet demand and certainly enough to ensure all single parents who want to work will not be impeded by a lack of access to care the trouble is those parents tend to live in local authority areas where councils find it hardest to provide quality services heres a prediction councils at the lower end of the audit commissions forthcoming comprehensive performance assessment will be those where the need for quality childcare is greatest the strategy unit simply ignores the problem of the variability of local authority services

text: it is a curious thing but the more that men and women do the same jobs the more their roles are assessed according to gender at the recent chartered institute of personnel and development cipd conference a fringe seminar stirred up controversy by suggesting that men and women learn differently if you thought that such a view was outdated then apparently you would be wrong according to michael carroll a chartered counselling psychologist from right coutts an international change management consultancy it is an idea that has gained a lot of ground women are supposed to have a better command of what are called the softer skills such as communication which are currently highly prized by modern management men on the other hand are considered to be a troubled lot as carroll reminded his audience men make up of the prison population and account for of all suicides and their suicide rate has risen by over the past decade on average they live six years less than women but their lives are more crowded as well as being three times more likely to be alcoholics of men work long hours compared with of women yet there is no evidence that this catalogue of woes adds up to a future where men will be left behind it remains a fact that men still predominate in boardrooms and the senior echelons of the professions while it is fashionable to assume that men must adapt to a womens world a more hardheaded analysis would suggest that ambitious women should study male behaviour which brings us back to the point of the cipd seminar we should not fall into easy assumptions that any approach to learning is the right one roy bolton regional manager for right coutts admits wryly that gender is something of a smokescreen here what has really changed is the nature of training or rather its object which as often as not is to train employees to find work elsewhere in the wake of mergers and redundancies the organisation man is dead and in a world where only change is certain men and women must learn to think for themselves

text: working parents will be denied childcare because of delays in the vetting of new childminders and nurseries carried out by the schools watchdog ofsted carers have been forced to wait over a year for clearance in some cases thanks to a backlog that is now putting the governments promised expansion of childcare places in jeopardy pressure groups claimed yesterday delays in routine checks on existing carers could tempt parents to leave their children with minders who had not been properly cleared tory mps warned only just over half the new applicants to the watchdog which took over the job of inspecting childcare last autumn had even been visited by the end of september let alone cleared to start work according to ofsted figures released last week this is going to put the brakes on expansion said stephen burke of the daycare trust which campaigns for better childcare the crunch is for parents whose expectations are being raised about the level of provision the reality is going to be very different on the ground the news comes as downing streets troubleshooting strategy unit prepares to release a report on the childcare industry this month expected to examine why new nurseries are not springing up fast enough to meet needs ofsted blames part of the problem on delays caused by the criminal records bureau set up to check the records of people working with children but insiders say it has also been hit by teething troubles of its own particularly with computer systems crashing when inspectors try to file reports so far it has only inspected about half the existing nurseries and childminders now in business who require yearly checks the national childminding association ncma says childminders applying for a variation of their registration to take on extra duties also face delays if a childminder needs to vary the conditions of their registration because the parent has to go abroad on an emergency business trip and they need to have overnight care for the child that could take three weeks said gill haynes chief executive of the ncma it is that sort of sensitivity to the needs of parents which has actually got to be part of the regulatory system otherwise people will just buck the system and turn a blind eye the tories warned parents not be tempted to risk informal arrangements with childminders who had not been checked the government has a duty to set up a system which does what it is meant to do protect children but let professional people who are not going to pose any threat get on with their jobs said eleanor laing shadow education spokeswoman there is enormous demand from parents and lack of supply and this is simply bureaucracy holding things up there are enormous implications of a situation like this going wrong the government has promised thousands more childcare places by raising fears among childcare providers over whether ofsted will be able to cope the watchdog insists it will meet targets to get all new checks done by march there are good reasons why it takes quite a long time we need to make sure we do thorough checks said a spokeswoman

the plan was a target to create one million childcare places by march to stand any chance of achieving this the government needed to recruit tens of thousands of new childcare workers but with less than months to go many experts including influential thinktank demos have begun to question whether the government can meet its deadline childcare in britain is still the most expensive in europe and although the government has introduced tax credits to help some families to pay for it prices are still rising inexorably as demand outstrips supply the typical cost of a nursery place for a child under two is now a year according to the daycare trust up on last year childminders are less expensive but a fulltime place would still typically cost nearly a year to tackle the shortage the government has launched recruitment drive after recruitment drive the biggest was an m advertising campaign launched in july which aims to attract new workers by but while recruitment seems to be rising for nurseries playgroups and outofschool clubs the number of childminders the most flexible of childcare workers so in theory the most useful to working parents is on the decline far from recruiting an extra or even new registered childminders all targets bandied about in the past few years we appear to have mislaid at least since from around childminders catering for up to children in england the numbers have fallen to around overall numbers for the uk are harder to come by but it seems clear that there are no more than in the uk while the number of nursery places has risen sufficiently to more than take up the slack nurseries tend to be more expensive they also tend to operate only within normal ninetofive monday to friday working hours that just doesnt suit a lot of parents says a spokeswoman for the national childminding association childminders by contrast are very flexible tend to work longer hours and can support shift workers childminding has always suffered from a high turnover according to surveys as many as threequarters say they started because they wanted to stay at home and care for their own children at the same time when these children reach school age parents frequently abandon childminding in favour of a betterpaid career a spokesperson for the department for education and skills dfes admits existing workers are leaving faster than it can register new ones but claims the trend is changing the fall in the number of childminders has been due to a variety of factors demographic changes have meant there are now fewer women with young children available to become childminders than years ago she says the government has piled m into startup grants to encourage more people to become registered childminders it has also secured m from the european social fund to help local authorities subsidise fees for childcare courses ongoing sustainability grants of up to a year are also available despite this only of childminders actually seem remain dominated by women who have preschool age children bad news for those looking for a fast rise in the number of available places but good news for mothers looking for a flexible way to earn money and bring up their children how you could become a registered childminder do i have to be registered to look after children yes if you look after children under eight for more than two hours a day on domestic premises other than the childs own home babysitters who look after children only between pm and am do not have to be registered neither do nannies how do i become a registered childminder attend a preregistration briefing run by your local council you will get information on training grants and the demand in your area at the end you will be given an application pack you they also insist on first aid training ofsted will carry out checks on your health and suitability to look after children as well as that of any assistant working for you it will also send an inspector to your home to check its suitability and to assess how many children you can care for you any assistants working for you and all overs living in your home also need to be checked out by the criminal records bureau before you get your registration certificate you must pay ofsted it will inspect you each year and will require an annual fee more details are available from ofsted charges vary dramatically even within a few miles so it makes sense to check out the competition according to the ncma the average per child is just per hour although the charges it has found range free legal representation and advice adding it to your home insurance is also an option and you should in any case inform your buildings and contents insurer that you are running a business from home norwich union charges to add on million of public liability insurance you will also need to extend your car insurance to cover business use insurance and other expenses can be offset against income when you pay your taxes through selfassessment each year you will also need to register with the inland revenue as selfemployed and start paying a week class national insurance unless you are a very low earner you will also need to pay class national insurance on profits

text: men accused of rape and sexual assault can no longer question their alleged victims in scottish courts under legislation which came into force yesterday the new law which is framed to make women less apprehensive about coming forward with rape allegations brings scotland in line with the rest of the uk but the measures go a step further than in england and wales in scotland an alleged victims sexual history can now only be brought up by defence lawyers if the defendants previous history of sexual offences is disclosed to the jury under the sexual offence procedure and evidence scotland act anyone charged with a sex offence will be required to appoint a solicitor or have one appointed by the court defence lawyers will also have to tell the court at least days before trial if they intend to bring up the victims sexual history if they do this the crown has the automatic right to disclose any previous convictions for sexual offences to the jury although the defence will be able to appeal to have this right waived the new law is likely to lead to many more cases in which the defendants criminal record is an issue than at present the legislation comes in the wake of a string of court cases in scotland where women were subjected to sustained and personal questioning by their alleged attackers the scottish justice minister jim wallace said the aim of this legislation is to reduce some of the fear that deters victims from coming forward he added the executive does not believe that victims should be subjected to intense often degrading questioning from the very person who is accused of abusing them sandy brindley spokeswoman for glasgow rape crisis welcomed the act but said more needed to be done to increase the conviction rate its not going to fully address the concerns that are there about the justice system she said

text: playworkers can be found working in adventure playgrounds afterschool clubs or school holiday playschemes usually with children aged from four to when it comes to child protection we have the same problems as schools in that it takes months for ofsted to vet staff in the meantime we have no choice but to rely on our instincts and hope for the best as there is a serious lack of available staff this is of course due to playworks poor salary and low profile not unrelated issues searching society guardians website revealed only a twoyear old report on staff recruitment in scotland a reflection of this low profile i agree with polly toynbee who states that there should be childrens centres across the country an average yearold has of his or her time free much research points to the fact that play is not a luxury for children it is a biological necessity children whose play opportunities are limited do not develop physical emotional and social skills which they will need to call upon in the rest of their lives if you have never fallen eight feet out of a tree how do you know for sure whether it will hurt where do children go to play in a contemporary society which builds on every scrap of available land adventure playgrounds provide a safe supervised environment and playworkers provide opportunities for children to fulfil their developmental needs but without recognition for playwork and child care in general i fear well be unable to recruit the staff to embark upon the vital project of establishing childrens centres nationwide

text: date rape and rape by a husband or partner must be treated as seriously by the courts as rape by a stranger the lord chief justice said yesterday issuing the first rape guidelines for years lord woolf adopted recommendations by the independent sentencing advisory panel which concluded from a public opinion survey that the impact of rape on the victim was equally serious whatever his or her relationship with the offender lord woolf took the opportunity of three rape appeals to issue the first guidance for judges in the crown courts on sentencing in date rape marital rape and male rape cases when the former lord chief justice lord lane issued the last guidance in he was silent on whether rapes within relationships should be treated less seriously than those by strangers marital rape and rape of males were not mentioned because they were not then considered rape by the law the advisory panel had urged the court of appeal to make a clear statement that when it came to passing sentence cases of relationship rape and acquaintance rape were to be treated as seriously as stranger rape lord woolf sitting with lord justice rose and mrs justice hallett also agreed that rape of a male by another male was equally serious and there was no inherent distinction between anal and vaginal rape he stressed that the appropriate sentence would depend on the mitigating and aggravating factors in each individual case and warned judges against applying the guidelines in a mechanistic or indiscriminate way which could result in inappropriately high or low sentences lord woolf confirmed that the starting points laid down by lord lane for judges when considering how long a sentence to pass will now apply to all rapes regardless of the relationship between victim and offender these are five years in custody for a single rape on an adult victim eight years for rapes with an aggravating feature such as gang rapes homophobic rapes or rape of a child years for a serial rapist and life for a perverted or psychopathic rapist who is likely to remain a danger to the public in practice many relationship rapes will continue to attract lower sentences than stranger rapes because of mitigating factors in the former or aggravating factors in the latter lord woolf said that when a couple sharing the same bed had been out drinking and the man failed to show the restraint he should have it would be contrary to common sense to treat what happened as equivalent to stranger rape giving an example of a case of marital rape for which lord taylor a former lord chief justice had reduced the sentence from three years to months lord woolf said the courts today would now consider three years the right sentence but in two of the three cases before the court yesterday the victims had been raped by expartners in a particularly brutal way and the court upheld the sentences of nine and years in the third case the court reduced from five years to four the sentence passed on a yearold guilty of raping a yearold male friend lord woolf urged the home secretary david blunkett to give greater priority to the shortage of treatment programmes for young sex offenders the lord chief justice said members of the public interviewed in the panels survey had found it unacceptable that a plea of guilty should result in a shorter sentence but that was because they saw it as primarily about saving court time and costs and allowing the defendant to manipulate the system in his favour the real reason for a reduced sentence was that a guilty plea spared the victim the trauma of giving evidence

text: they cant sack me im pregnant many people believe that being pregnant automatically safeguards their job but while your employer cant give you the heaveho just because you are expecting they can still sack you for all the usual reasons you can also be made redundant while you are on maternity leave if your employer can prove your post is no longer valid companies arent allowed to question candidates about their private lives in a job interview while employment specialists advise employers to tread carefully when asking interviewees about their private lives there is nothing in law which says they cannot do so if for example the job requires you to work unsociable hours or to relocate it would be reasonable for the interviewer to ask you whether you have a family or outside commitments however such questions would have to be asked equally of all candidates both male and female to avoid suggestions of discrimination i dont have to work public holidays it depends what your contract says there is nothing in law which says employees have the right to take the day off on public holidays likewise you are only entitled to extra pay for working public holidays or weekends if it says so in your contract you have to have two verbal warnings and a written warning before you are dismissed not always although this is the path usually taken by employers when they want to get rid of a member of staff they can sometimes go straight to the written warning stage depending on the severity of the offence commit gross misconduct however urinate in the wastepaper basket give the boss a black eye or get caught with your hand in the petty cash box and you can be dismissed on the spot im entitled to a onehour lunchbreak the onehour lunchbreak which most of us expect has more to do with convention than legal requirements the law says that for every block of six hours you work you must have a minute break although this has to be taken somewhere in the middle of your shift rather than at the beginning or end it doesnt necessarily have to be at lunchtime you have to have worked for an organisation for more than one year before you have any rights although it is generally true that you can only take your employer to a tribunal for unfair dismissal if you have worked for them for over a year there are exceptions if for example you had worked somewhere for just under one year before you were asked to leave you could argue that your employment was deliberately cut short you could also argue that owed holiday or a notice period would have taken you past the oneyear guideline however you have rights against discrimination on the grounds of race disability gender sexual orientation religion and trade union membership from day one of your employment the same is true for breach of contract i have to give a months notice because im paid monthly only if it says so in your contract the legal requirement is one week in return your employer has to give you a weeks notice for every complete year of service with a maximum of weeks unless your contract says otherwise if my employer gets rid of me i will get compensation not necessarily you will be entitled to some compensation if you are made redundant that is to say your post within the organisation is no longer needed or the company closes down the amount you get will depend on your age and the length of time you have been in your job if you are sacked for anything other than gross misconduct you are only entitled to the notice period in your contract or payment in lieu of this despite the sixfigure sums that hit the headlines most people are surprised to learn that compensation for unfair dismissal is usually quite low ive got a right to be treated reasonably by my employer sadly although there are laws to protect you against intimidation discrimination and constructive dismissal in the workplace there is nothing which says your employer has to be nice to you so if you work in a stressful environment where people work to tight deadlines and lose their tempers its tough luck advice courtesy of diane sinclair adviser to the chartered institute of personnel and development and richard lister employment lawyer with lewis silkin for more information go to wwwacasorguk the following correction was printed in the guardians corrections and clarifications column monday december we said in this article that rights protecting employees against discrimination because of among other things sexual orientation began on day one of their employment in fact the relevant legislation is not yet on the statute book but is expected to be by the end of next year

text: chancellor gordon brown polished up his childfriendly credentials last week promising to help increase the number of workplace nurseries and crches and announcing financial help for some parents who use approved childcare within their own homes there are only about workplace nurseries and crches in the uk the chancellor aims to encourage more employers to offer childcare facilities through tax and national insurance incentives the details of which will be set out in the forthcoming document balancing work and family life enhancing choice and support for parents donna and nick johnson whose first baby noah was born seven weeks ago hope the tax breaks will enable their employers to extend existing childcare provision for staff the couple are both registrar paediatricians donna works at kings college hospital and nick at st georges hospital in london they have both applied for places on their respective employers nursery schemes which cost about a week but as nick points out there is no guarantee of a place about people work at the st georges trust many of whom are women with young children and there are just places he says even if noah gets a place the hours could still prove difficult the st georges nursery scheme operates between am and pm with extensions to pm on mondays and thursdays only nick says he and donna will try to negotiate their work timetables so that they are not on call at the same time but adds sometimes things can fall apart and it wont be that easy megan pacey of the daycare trust says the nhs has its own childcare strategy which may not be affected by the tax incentives directly but that they could encourage corporate employers to combine forces with public sector employers in the same locality to provide cooperative childcare facilities the chancellor also announced plans to extend the childcare element of the working tax credit to those who use approved childcare in their home benefiting parents of disabled children and parents who work outside conventional hours the move will provide parents who each work at least hours a week with a tax credit of up to per cent of the first a week of childcare costs for a single child or per cent of the first a week of costs for two children but the credit tapers to zero for parents earning a household income of or more for one child and for two children this is expected to apply only to registered child minders initially but martin barnes of the child poverty action group says the plan is likely to be extended to enable nannies to register as approved home child carers the prebudget statement offered no specific help for single parents but they will benefit from the child tax credit which will be introduced in april next year teresa goodman whose son nathan is works parttime rather than using afterschool childcare and so will not benefit from the changes but she says i still regard gordon as my friend under labour ive paid slightly less in tax and interest rates have stayed low which has helped with the mortgage lights are on green most householders will need to start recycling bottles and other waste in the next few years or start paying extra sums for refuse collection as a result of the prebudget statement a consultation was announced to look at a range of incentives for recycling as predicted in cash landfill tax will be doubled over the next few years which will not hit householders directly but could lead to rises in council tax
